div.p: THE ART OF Preerving and Retoring HEALTH.
Explaining the Nature and Caues of the Ditempers that afflict Mankind.
Alo hewing That every Man is, or may be, his own bet Phyician.
To which is added A Treatie of the mot Simple and Effectual Remedies for the Dieaes of Men and Women.
Written in French by M. Flamand, M. D. and faithfully tranlated into Englih.
LONDON, Printed for R. Bently, in Covent-Garden; H. Bonwick, in St. Paul's Church-yard; and S. Manhip, at the Ship in Cornhill. 1697.

div.head: THE French Author's PREFACE.
div.p:
I Shall have all the Reaon in the World to complain of the Injutice of the Public, if my Charitable Deign in Publihing this little Treatie be look'd upon as an effect of my Vanity, or an Arrogant Undertaking to precribe Rules to Phyicians. I am enible of the vat acknowledgments we owe for
the daily and important dicoveries they make in that ueful Art; and that they do not tand in need of any Light to direct 'em, but what they acquire by their own Experience and Studies. I never entertain'd a Thought of controverting the jut Right they are poes'd of, to give Laws to the ret of Mankind; nor was ever guilty of the leat Intention to diwade my Readers from following the Intructions of their lawful Guides: My only Deign was to erve the Neceities of thoe, who, tho' they are not profes'd
Phyicians, are nevertheles Maters of a ufficient Stock of Sene and Judgment, and are neither too crupulouly fond, nor unreaonably negligent of their Health; for 'tis eertain that the two oppoite Extremities are equally to be avoided upon all Occaions. I hope I hall eaily obtain pardon for retaining ome Terms of Art, when the Subject cou'd not be ditinctly handl'd without 'em, epecially ince I have always taken care to explain 'em. I never intended to court any Approbation but that of the Candid Reader; and I hall
think my elf abundantly recompens'd for all my Labour, if there be any thing found in my Book that may deerve it.

div.head: OBSERVATION I.
That Man is endu'd with Intinct.
div.p: THE Word Intinct may be conider'd, either according to its Signification or Etymology.
Intinct, according to the Etymology, comes from the Latin Word Intigo; which in Englih ignifies to incite, tir up, &c.
According to the ignification, Intinct in Beats is an Impule, which moves them towards thoe things that are ueful, and makes them hun thoe things that are hurtful.

This is the Opinion of Plato, Socrates, Aritotle, and, in a Word, of all the ancient Philoophers: But, according to des Cartes, and other modern Writers, the Intinct of Beats is a certain Principle, which is the caue of all their Actions, jut as the Wheels of a Watch make it point out and trike the Hours; for, according to the Moderns, Beats are nothing but a ort of Clock-Work, or meer Machines: But this Opinion begins to loe Ground, as well as others.

This being premis'd, we may define the Intinct of Animals to be a Power of Acting; which is, as it were, the Caue of the Actions that contribute to their Preervation, which we commonly acribe to their Intinct And may not Man then have uch a Principle, which in him may be the Caue of the like Actions? if we conider him purely as an Animal, for, Abtrahentium non et mendacium, ay the Philoophers, we may preume that Man, as well as the Beats, acts by Intinct for his own Preervation.

Reaon and Experience confirm this Truth; for it cannot be deny'd, that Man in his Infancy, while Reaon is clogg'd and obcur'd by the Imperfections of the Organs of his Body, does many things which are advantageous to him, and which can not proceed but from that Principle which is common to him with the Beats, ince at that time he has no ue of his Reaon; for we find that an Infant, aoon as 'tis born, applies it elf
to the Nipple which is preented to it by the Mother or Nure, and ucks out the Milk, without conidering that it wants it for its Nourihment. And oon after, when the Organs of his Senes are trengthen'd, and when he begins to fix his Eyes upon uch Objects as preent themelves to his ight, do not we ee that he endeavours to avoid thoe that are diagreeable to him; that he cries and is troubled when an unknown or deform'd Peron takes him out of his Nure's Arms? And is it not plain that thee are the Effects of Intinct, ince Beats do the ame, without the Light of Reaon.

But we are not only guided by Intinct during our Infancy, for we are enible of it even in the Vigour of our Age. How often does it happen that while our Thoughts are
• ntent upon ome important Affair, we approach the Fire in the Winter, or eat a hearty Meal, and do everal other things without thinking on them.

Cato the Cenor, one of the wiet Perons among the Romans, was Phyician to himelf, and to his whole Family; and he who writes his Life, tells us, that that Illutrious Roman was wont to boat that he always kept himelf and his Family in per
• ect Health, by the help of uch Phyick as he prepar'd himelf; which is as much as
• f he had intimated to us, that he was a di
• igent Oberver of the Dictates of Nature.

Montaigne, one of the mot refin'd Wit •
of our Age, relates the ame of his Ancetors, in the Second Book of his Eays, Chap. 3 •
My Father, ays he, liv'd eventy four Years my Grand-father ixty nine, and my Great Grandfather near eighty, without o much as tating any Medicines; for whatoever was not commonly us'd, erv'd them intead of Drugs.

Nevertheles, 'tis certain that he did no •
write this becaue he had an Averion to Phyick, for he was too wie and judicious no •
to have a particular value for o ueful a •
Art; as appears by another Paage of hi •
Works, where he exprees himelf in the ••
Words, Health is a precious thing, which rea •
deerves that a Man hou'd employ not only b •
time, but every thing ele, for its Preervation.

If Men will join Reaon to their Natural Intinct, they may know themelves be •
ter than the Beats can poibly do, whic •
perhaps have no Knowledge, or at le •••
are incapable of Reflexion.

I am not ignorant that Monieur de <>
Chambre, a very Learned and Eminent Phyician, hath written a particular Treatie co •
cerning the Reaoning of Beats: But t ••
Reader will give me leave to own that <>
am neither of his Opinion, nor of that <>
ome other Philoophers, who affirm th ••
Beats act formally and directly for the a •
taining of their End, tho' in an imperfe ••
manner; ince, according to the Philoopher •
the ditinction of Degrees, or More and Le ••
does not imply a pecial Difference; and ince there is no Effect that does not depend upon, or proceed from, an Internal Caue, which can hardly be allow'd to Beats.

Beides, Reaon enables a Man to chooe, out of many Remedies, that which he knows to be the mot proper for himelf; whereas all other Animals of the ame Species, ue the ame Remedies, becaue they are not capable of making o nice a Ditinction.

To conclude; as 'tis plain that certain Junctures of Time, and other Circumtances, have a coniderable influence upon the Effect of Medicines, it mut alo be acknowledged as wholly owing to Reaon, that a Man who has made ue of the ame Remedies at different times, when he comes to reflect upon their various Effects, is able with more exactnes and Judgment to chooe fit Opportunities to ecure or promote their Succes. 'Tis thus that many Husbandmen, Labourers, and other Country People preerve their Health for the pace of eventy or eighty Years, and live to a great Age, without having need of any but their own Internal Phyician, that is, their natural Intinct, and the Light of their Reaon, which admonihes 'em to avoid Debauchery, Exces, and Ambition.

'Tis certain then that we can make ue of no better Phyicians than our elves, provided we wou'd eriouly apply our elves to the Preervation of our Health and Strength, and di
• igently follow our Intinct and the Light of our Reaon.

div.head: OBSERVATION II.

Of the Temperaments or Contitution •
of Bodies, and of the Caues of Dieaes in general.
div.p:
'T WOU'D be needles to trouble th •
Reader with the Definition or Etymology of the Word Temperament or Contitution and its Diviion into nine different Species which are the common Subjects of Diputation in the Schools; ince there are ver •
few who know not that a Temperament
•
nothing ele but a Mixture of the four Qualities, viz. Heat, Coldnes, Moiture and Drynes.

And on the other Hand, tho' a Man hou ••
know that there are nine Species of Temperaments, viz. one temperate, and the other eight intemperate, he wou'd not, perhaps, b •
the more Learned; Nevertheles, let my Silence hou'd be imputed to Ignorance, I wi ••
give uch an account of 'em, as may in om •
meaure atisfie the Reader's Curioity.

The Temperate Contitution is that which is compoed of a due and convenient Mixture of the four firt Qualities, either according to the Quantity, which we call a Temperate Contitution ad pondus, i. e. to weight
or according to the Quality, ad jutitiam, fit for every Faculty to perform its Operations aright. I leave it to be decided by my more Learned and Experienc'd Brethren, whether they ever met with uch a Contitution in their Practice.
An Intemperate Contitution is that in which there is an Exces of one or more Qualities above the Temperate; and it is twofold, viz. Simple and Compound.
The Simple is that which is caued by the Exces of any one Quality, viz. Hot, Cold, Dry, or Moit eparately.

The Compound is that which is produc'd by the Exces of two or more Qualities: Thus Heat and Moiture conjunctly make a Sanguine Contitution, which anwers to Adolecency and the Spring; Heat and Drynes agree with Youth; Choler, and the Summer; and o of the ret.

An Intemperate Contitution, as well Simple as Compound, may be either Healthful or Sickly, Equal or Unequal, with or without Matter, &c. But ince thee Ditinctions wou'd engage me in unprofitable Debates, I refer the Reader to thoe Authors who have treated on that Subject.

And tho' the Knowledge of the Contitutions may be of ome ue, to dicover the Inclinations of Men, and many Dieaes to which they are ubject, I will chue rather to ay with a late Author, that there are but two orts of Perons, one that are
endow'd with a healthy and trong Contitution; and the other with a feeble and weak Contitution, who are almot always ick, and enjoy but very little Health.

'Tis a great Advantage to be naturally well-dipoed both in Body and Mind; for uch a Peron may enjoy a perfect Health by leading a regular Life: But when one is naturally of an ill Contitution, he loes his Health as often as he neglects the Admonitions of his Intinct, and conequently mut lead a very troublome and uneaie Life.

div.head: CHAP. I.
Of the principal Caues of Dieaes in the general.
div.p: THERE are four Caues of Dieaes viz. two remote, which are Melancholy or Vexation, and Debauchery; and two immediate, which are an exces of Blood, and the too long continuance of the Excrements in the great Guts.

div.head: The firt remote Caue of Dieaes: Of the bad Effects which it produces both in the Body and Mind; and of its Remedies.
div.p: THere are very few Perons who are not acquainted with Melancholy, either by Reaon or Experience, ince the Life of Man is a continual Revolution of Properity and Adverity; and the Oppoitions betwixt thoe two Conditions, excite in us contrary Motions, and very different Paions. That Tranquillity of Mind which accompanies good Fortune, is very proper to preerve the Health; for tho' the Mind and the Body are of a different Nature, yet they have an Affinity, which keep 'em in uch Dependance one to the other, that there is nothing regularly done in the whole Compoition, unles it be carry'd on by an equal Combination of the two Parts.

All our Actions are perform'd by the aitance of the Vital and Animal Spirits; and 'tis their Commerce which maintains that perfect Union, between the Heart and the Brain, which are the principal Organs of the Body. For 'tis plain that the Brain cannot produce the Animal Spirits, unles the ubtil
parts of the Blood be convey'd thither through the Arteries; and that the Heart, which is a Mucle, hath not power by its continual Motion, to diffue the Blood through the whole Body, but by the aitance of the Animal Spirits: Now when the Mind is erene and unditurb'd, that all the Parts may be enible of her Impreions, he furnihes 'em with a ufficient quantity of Spirits, to enable 'em to perform their repective Actions.

But, on the other hand, when the Mind is agitated with a Croud of dimal Apprehenions, that give Entrance to Grief and Melancholy, he is perpetually ruminating on the Caues of her Diaters, and endeavouring with all imaginable Application, to remove 'em, which mut needs occaion a vat expence of Spirits. So that all the Animal Spirits which are generated in the Brain, are carce able to upply thoe Parts which are ubervient to the deigns of the Soul, in the performance of thoe haty Motions he requires from 'em; and conequently ince o large a quantity of the Spirits flows into the Nerves, that are betow'd upon thoe Parts, there are but few left for the other Nerves: Now the Parts which help to change or diget the Aliments, and are ubervient to all the Actions which are call'd Natural, being of no ue to the Paions, 'tis plain that the Nerves which go to thoe Parts, receive but few Spirits from the Brain, and
conequently that their Fibres are very weakly mov'd, and their Actions diorderly and irregular; o that the Excrements can hardly be expell'd; and their too long continuance in the Guts is the immediate Caue of Dieaes.

We may add, that the great diipation of the Animal Spirits, when the Soul is vex'd and diturb'd, is the occaion that a greater quantity of Blood than uual is ent from the Heart to the Brain, to make up the Los of thoe Spirits; and conequently the Nourihment of all the other Parts is both much leen'd and chang'd as to its quality. For 'tis always the bet part of the Blood that runs to the Brain, and the Body is depriv'd of its bet Nourihment, particularly the Membranous Parts, which are weakned and dry'd up, for want of fit Matter to preerve them; and this Inconveniency reaching the Intetines, as well as all the other Parts, 'tis certain that they cannot expel the Excrements with vigour, by their Vermicular or Peritaltick Motion, being depriv'd of the Animal Spirits, by whoe Aitance they were moved.

We alo ee, that thoe who are naturally of a melancholy and peevih Humour, who apply themelves to tudy, or to other Employments, which require much application, are uually lean, and ubject to be often Cotive, and commonly fancy themelves to be extremely ick, before they have the leat dipoition or tendency to Sicknes.

div.head: What ought to be done in order to prevent the Effects of Grief or Melancholy.
div.p: ALL Dieaes, as well of the Body as of the Mind, may be cured either perfectly or imperfectly.

A perfect Cure conits in the entire detruction of all the Caues of the Dieae, which mut necearily ceae when the Caues are remov'd; Sublatâ causâ tollitur effectus: This ort of Cure is call'd cradicative.
Grief is not only a Dieae of the Body, but 'tis one of the mot coniderable Ditempers that can poibly afflict the Mind.

It cannot be always cur'd by an entire removal of its Caues, ince they are not always in our power; and the bet Reaons that can be alledged, to peruade a Man to raie himelf by the Strength of his Mind, above the reach of Ill Fortune, may erve indeed for a fine Amuement to a contemplative Genius; but are rarely able to allay the torment of an afflicted Mind: For as it is eaie for thoe on whom Fortune miles, to comfort the Mierable, o it is hard for thoe who are in trouble not to feel the weight of their Misfortunes.

As for Example; if a Man was entirely ruin'd, or reduc'd to extreme want by a litigious Action enter'd againt him by his Enemies;
a grave Philoopher might indeed admonih him that the Etate he had lot was tranitory and perihable, and that he ought not to have ettl'd his Affections on it, neither as a Man, becaue he hou'd have conider'd that he mut have left it ooner or later; nor as a Chritian, becaue as uch he ought not to look upon uch fleeting Enjoyments as his Portion, but upon thoe which are Everlating? Thee are certain and undoubted Truths, but wou'd not, in all probability quiet the Mind of a Peron in uch Circumtances, or make him forget his Los. And 'tis no les certain that the Recovery of his Etate wou'd be the mot effectual Expedient to retore the Tranquility of his Mind.
Grief may be alo occaion'd by many other Caues, which are no les without our power, and beyond the reach of Medicines, than the former.

But that which eems to be peculiar to this troubleome Ditemper, is, that whereas other Ditempers are commonly cur'd by things that are contrary to 'em; that which is contrary to this, commonly augments, rather than abates the Ditemper.

For a Man who is drowned in Sorrow is incapable of taking Pleaure in any thing; and Joy, which is oppoite to his Grief, is o far from eaing him, that he cannot endure to perceive the leat appearance of it in another.

'Twou'd be needles then to attempt the Cure by endeavouring to divert his Thoughts; and therefore, (in expectation that Time, which is the only Phyician in uch Caes, may heal the Wounds of his Mind, or ome of thoe unexpected Revolutions, to which all the World is ubject, may put an end to the Caue of his Sorrow) we mut content our elves with peruading him at leat to reit the fatal Influence which this Paion may have upon his bodily Health, becaue of the trict Union that is between thoe two Parts which compoe the Man.

'Tis certain that Grief may be the Spring and Fountain of many Dieaes, by cauing the Excrements to remain too long in the great Guts: And therefore we mut endeavour to make the bet ue of the Signs by which the Internal Phyician acquaints us with the toppage of thoe Impurities in thee Paages, let the Mind hou'd by degrees communicate the infectious Contagion of its Ditemper, to the Body; that is, we mut expel thoe Excrements as oon as we perceive any igns of fulnes; and in order to this, we mut chue the mot convenient Medicines. For, as I intimated before, we mut either entirely remove the Caues of a Dieae, or at leat endeavour to prevent their Fatal Effects.

div.head: Of Debauchery or Intemperance,
The Second remote Caue of Dieaes.
div.p: DEbauchery conits chiefly in two things, viz. in exces of Drinking and Eating, and in the immoderate ue of the Pleaures of Love; for 'tis by this means that the mot healthy Perons detroy themelves, and horten their Days, even tho' they be otherwie of a tronger Contitution than others.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of Exces in Drinking and Eating.
div.p:
THAT we may comprehend the manner how Dieaes are occaion'd by exces in Eating and Drinking, we mut examine the Action of the Stomach and Guts in converting the Food into Chyle: for if we conider that all the Fibres which compoe the Contexture of thoe Parts, are as it were o many mall Springs, being which ucceively lacken'd and contracted, keep the Food in a continual Motion, which, with the aitance of diolving Acids, attenuates, bruies, and entirely changes
its Nature. Now 'tis plain that thee Springs may loe their force and activity by a continual Preure and ditenion, occaion'd by an exceive quantity of Food, which fills the Spaces that are formed by their Turnings and Windings, even as the Springs of our Machines are topt when their Relaxation is hinder'd by a trong Preure: For as a Bow cannot long retain its Spring if it be kept continually bent, and the finet Machine in the World will decay inenibly if it be not diligently kept in Order, o the mot vigorous Stomach may be poil'd by an over-proportion'd quantity of Food, becaue the Fibres both of that and of the other Parts which help Digetion, are either broken, or o weaken'd by a continual Extenion, that they cannot afterwards contract and expand themelves, either to concoct the Food, or to expel the Excrements that are eparated from it: Now Indigetion and the Stoppage of the Excrements in the Body, are, in a great meaure, the immediate Caues of Dieaes.

But let us uppoe that the Stomach, tho loaded with Food, may nevertheles be able to diget it when the Body is very trong and vigorous, what mut be the conequence of uch a Digetion, but that the redundant Chyle flowing out of the Stomach, and not being admitted into the Milky-Veels of the Meenterium, mut remain in the mall Guts, and afterwards pas with the Excrements into the
greater, where it mut quickly be corrupted, for want of a ufficient ferment to keep up its Motion, and conequently mut of neceity corrupt the Excrements, and occaion all thoe Diorders which hall be mentioned in the Chapters that treat of the immediate Caues of Dieaes.

We ought therefore diligently to avoid exces in Drinking and Eating; and for that reaon 'tis neceary that every one hould be acquainted with his own Contitution: As for Example; the Cholerick have occaion to eat oftener than the Phlegmatick, becaue thoe are much hotter than thee, and the Heat not meeting with Matter to diget, takes hold of the Alimentary Juice, and thereby inenibly weakens the principal parts of the Body.

Whoever enjoys a perfect Health, ought to ue indifferently every thing that is fit to Nourih him, epecially when he has oberv'd that any particular ort of Food is endu'd with all the neceary Qualities; as firt, when it is agreeable to the Tate; for when the Stomach loaths any particular kind of Meat, tho' at the ame time it be very good and wholome, we ought to abtain from it, becaue it will infallibly either caue Indigetion, or provoke Vomiting.

Secondly, When 'tis eaily digeted, without occaioning either a lacknes or traitnes in the Belly: Thee are the uret Marks of
wholome Food; and there remains nothing more to be oberv'd, but that the Quantity mut always be moderate. We mut then, to preerve our Health, eat when we are hungry, and drink when we are thirty, whatoever is proper to be eaten or drunk, without forcing Nature, and without either tarving or cloying our Stomachs.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Of the immoderate e of the Pleaures of Love.
div.p:
THIS ort of Intemperance is no les dangerous and prejudicial than the former: I need not mention thoe infamous Marks and Effects of Lechery, the Gonorrhaea both imple and virulent, Phimois, Paraphimois, Excrecencies, Bubo's, and in a Word, the Dieae which is commonly entertain'd by all Nations, tho' none of 'em are willing to own it as a Native, thee are the uual Conequences, and the jut Rewards of unbridl'd Lut. But beides, it is certain that the immoderate ue of thoe Pleaures diipates the Spirits, extremely weakens the Brain, robs the Nerves, and Membranous Parts of their proper Nourihment, is fatal to
thoe who have a weak Breat, heats and drys up the whole Body, and makes way for a whole Army of Dieaes, by weakening the Action of the great Guts, by diipating the Spirits, and by drying up the Fibres.

It is therefore neceary to moderate the Pleaures of Love, if we wou'd preerve our elves from irrecoverable Ruine; and conequently in our amorous Inclinations, we ought to conult our Strength, and never to give a full career to our eager Deires.

We mut be entirely Maters of our elves, that we may be able, upon Occaion, to curb the heat of a Paion which has in all Ages fooled the wiet Heads, and baffled the everet Vertue; ince the Widom of Solomon, the Holines of David, and the Strength of Sampon, could not moderate the Sallies of this ungoverneable Paion: And 'twas this that made the modet Virgil ay, Omnia vincit Amor, & nos cedamus Amori.

Reaon, which ought to guide us in all our Steps, is never les obey'd, nor more trangely puzzl'd than when he attempts to calm the impetuous Motions of Love, that are tirr'd up in us by an infinite Number of Objects, and after a thouand everal ways.

To make our elves Maters of this Paion, we mut not only be poet of an unhaken Firmnes and Reolution, but be furnih'd
with contant Supplies of Grace; for Chatity in Youth is a ort of Martyrdom, or as a Father of the Church terms it, Martyrium ine anguine.

This Conideration obliges me to advie all unmarry'd Perons to abtain entirely from the Pleaures that are propos'd to them by this Paion, provided their ordinary Food be not too Juicy and provocative, uch as new-laid Eggs, Capons, Partridges, Woodcocks, Pigeons, Artichokes, Aparagus, Celery, all orts of Salt and Pepper'd Meats; as alo ome kinds of Pule, becaue of their Windines, as Peae and Beans; and therefore uch Perons mut content themelves with les Nourihing Food, and cool their Bodies more or les, according to their Age and Contitutions; which they may do very eaily by conulting their Phyicians; for otherwie they may, by abtaining entirely from the Pleaures of Love, render themelves obnoxious to many Dieaes, as Stoppage of Urine, the Gravel, Stone, Vapours, Faintings, the Jaundice, and Green-Sicknes.

'Tis certain that an exceive ue of the Pleaures of Love is more dangerous than an entire abtinence from them; for the Ebullition of the Blood ending ooner or later with Age, the Paions are extinguih'd with it, and the Calm we enjoy after the Storm, makes us oon forget all the Pain we uffer'd to reit it: whereas the Inconveniencies that
remain after the immoderate ue of thoe Pleaures, uch as the trembling of the Nerves, Palie, Shortnes of Breath, Phthiis, Gout, &c. make us pay very dear, in a long and infirm Old Age, for the tranitory Charms we enjoy'd, and the frivolous Amuements of our Youth.
What has been aid may uffice to give us an Idea of the remote Caues of Dieaes; and therefore in the next place we mut proceed to conider their more immediate Caues.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Of the Redundancy or too great Abundance of Blood, the firt immediate Caue of Dieaes.
div.p: THE Blood, which is the Treaure of Life, when it exceeds either in Quantity or Quality, may prove the Caue of Death when there is more than a ufficient quantity of it in the Body, which we call a Plethora, or a fulnes of Blood; or when it hath acquired ome bad Quality, which we call Cacochymia, or a depravation of the Humours: Bleeding detroys or removes the former, and Purging the latter.
We may eaily comprehend how Dieaes may be occaion'd meerly by the Quantity of the Blood, if we reflect upon the Dipoition of the Organs which contain and convey the Blood, and conduce to its Motion.

In order to this we may compare the Veins and Arteries of our Bodies to the Pipes of a Fountain, the firt of which, or thoe that are next the Spring-head, are very big and large, but grow inenibly maller as they pread themelves into Branches; uppoing, for Example, that the firt gives paage to a Foot of Water, and that the lat do not give paage to above an Inch. The ame Obervations may be apply'd to the Blood-Veels.

The Arteries which proceed from the Heart are very large, and are divided into others of a middle bignes; thee again are divided into maller Branches which are ucceively ubdivided, till they become o mall, that they are uually call'd Capillarie (or Hairlike) and Inviible. And in all parts of the Body where thee inviible Arteries are found, they meet with very mall Veins, which grow larger as they meet, and join with one another, and return at length to the Heart, where they terminate, and are as large as the Arteries at their coming out of the Heart. Now the Blood flows thro' all thoe Pipes, and the Heart directs its Motion, as a Conduit-Maker directs that of the Water in the
Pipes of the Fountain. And as it often happens that the Water-Pipes are either topt or broken when a Body that is Bulky enough to fill up the Paage enters with the Water, or a greater quantity of Water than they can contain; o the Blood-Veels are frequently obtructed, and ometimes broken, when the Liquor they contain is either redundant, or thicker than it ought to be, from whence proceed Fevers, Ebullitions of the Blood, Abcees or Impotumes, both in the inward Parts, and upon the Surface of the Body, Bleeding at the Noe, and other Parts, Apoplexies, Suffocating Defluxions, and Obtructions of the Intrals, which make way for an infinite Number of Dieaes. But if the Abundance of Blood may be look'd upon as the Caue of o many Ditempers, 'tis certain that the depravation of it may produce a far greater Number of more tubborn and dangerous Dieaes.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Of the Depravation of the Blood, conider'd as an immediate Caue of Dieaes, occaion'd by the retaining of the Excrements in the Body.
div.p: SINCE the retaining of the Excrements in the great Guts is that which mot frequently makes the Blood loe that good Dipoition in which our Health conits, and occaions a Cacochymia which we have already intimated to be the Caue of the mot tubborn Dieaes; 'twill be convenient to give the Reader a comprehenive View of this fatal Source of Ditempers.

The Meat which we eat receives its firt Change in the Mouth, by the help of the Teeth, which are as it were mall natural Knives, to mince it; and of the Spittle, which may not improperly be aid to erve intead of Salt, to help its Concoction. From the Mouth 'tis carry'd through a long Chanel, which Anatomits call the Oeaphagus or Gullet, into a pacious Cavity, call'd the Stomach, where either by a proper and peculiar Vertue belonging to that Part, or by the help of an Acid, or ome other Ferment
which it meets with there, 'tis chang'd into a liquid and greyih Subtance, which they call Chyle. Then continuing its Journey downwards, it goes out of the Stomach by its inferiour Orifice, and lips into the upper part of the Intetines, to the everal Parts of which Anatomits have given different Names, according to certain Remarks and Obervations they have made upon thee Parts.

The firt part, which in the diection of everal Animals, they found to be about twelve Inches long, is call'd the Duodenum; that which follows, which ome pretend is not o full as the ret, is term'd the Jejunum; that which conits of mot Folds is call'd the Ileon; and o of the ret. The greatet part of this Intetine is faten'd about a Part, which by reaon of its Folds or Plaits, reembles thoe Ruffs that were formerly worn about the Neck, and is call'd the Meentery: Its Figure renders it very apt to retain in a mall pace a coniderable part of this Intetine, which is variouly wound or twited about its Folds.

'Tis in this part of the Intetines that the mot ueful part of the Chyle ininuates it elf into the Mouths of certain Veels, call'd the Lactean or Milky, which run along between the Membranes of the Meentery. And the groer Particles, which cannot enter into the Branches of thoe Veels, continuing their Coure, decend from that part of the Intetines
which is fix'd to the Meentery, and enter into the great Guts, where they are topt.

This being premis'd, I proceed to hew that the remaining part of the Chyle, which is properly an Excrement, after its entry into the great Guts, infecteth the Blood, by its too long continuance in that part wit •
a Cacochymia, which, as I intimated before, i •
the immediate Caue of mot of our Indipoitions: For ince the Excrements are unfit for Nourihment, and are of no ue in the great Guts, they cannot continue there long without Corruption. Now there can be n •
Corruption of any Matter without Fermertation, by which ome ubtil Particles a ••
looen'd and eparated from the corrupte •
Matter, which meeting with a Porous Subtance, are eaily dipert thro' it by the i •
petuoity of their Motion. Thus the Cacchymia is at lat communicated to the H •
mours; for the Excrements that remain lo ••
in the great Guts are fermented, after whic •
the Subtil Particles that are eparated by th •
Fermentation, triking againt the Sides <>
Coats of the Guts, find the Pores of th •••
Veels which urround them, fit to receiv •
them, and lipping into thoe Paages, communicate their Corruption to the Blood th ••
circulates thro' thoe Veels, which, co •
tinuing for a coniderable time, they inf •••
the whole Mas of Blood; and this Inf •
ction proves the Source of many Dieaes.

It may by objected, that it does not eem probable that the Excrements hou'd be corrupted by remaining in the Body, ince it has been oberv'd, that thoe which have remain'd long in the Body are not o tinking, as thoe that have lain there only o long as they ought to do naturally; that Stench is the mot certain Mark of Corruption, and that conequently the longer they tay they ought to tink the more, if they corrupted proportionably to the time of their continuance in the Guts.

But the reaon why the Excrements tink les when they have remain'd long in the Guts, is, becaue their Humidity is diipated by the continu'd Action of the Heat; for the moit Particles being rarify'd and ubtiliz'd by the Heat, exhale from the Mas of the Excrements, and finding, as I oberv'd before, the Pores of the Veels which environ the great Guts, dipoed to receive 'em, they lip into thee mall Paages, and produce an Alteration in all the Blood that paes that way, which makes it degenerate from its natural State; and therefore it will not follow that the Excrements which are retain'd are exempted from Corruption, becaue their Smell is not o offenive, but that the Heat having conum'd all the Moiture that was on their Surface, and having dry'd, or rather burnt it up, they cannot be uppos'd to yield o noiome a Smell as before thoe Steams were exhal'd.

The ame Alteration may be oberv'd in a Heap of Dung, which after it has been long expos'd to the Sun, cats forth no bad mell, provided it be not mov'd or agitated; but if it be turn'd or mov'd to the Bottom, it will moak, and cat forth a more noiome mell than when it was firt brought to the Dunghil. After the ame manner the Excrements that have remain'd long in the Body, are dry'd up in their Surface, and are carce offenive to the Smel •
when expell'd naturally; but when they are agitated by the Bile, as in a Dia •
rhoea or Loones, their Stench is inupportable.

It may further be objected, that the Vei ••
and Arteries which environ the great Guts are o inconiderable, that 'tis hard to conceiv •
how that little quantity of Blood which pa ••
thro' them, can poil the whole Mas, becaue th •
mall Portion of Blood being forthwith carry ••
back from thoe Veels into the Trunk <>
the Vena Porta, is freed from all its impurties; and even uppoing that there remain •
ome ill quality in it, it may be preum ••
that o mall a quantity of ill Blood pai ••
from the Roots of the Vena Porta into th •
Vena Cava, and from thence to the Heart, <>
o at lat mingling with all the Blood of <>
Body, can no more corrupt the whole Ma ••
than a Glas of Water thrown into a Hoghe ••
of Wine can weaken that Spirituous Liquo •

For a atisfactory Anwer to this Objection, we mut examine whether the Liver is able to purge the Blood of all its Impurities: now 'tis certain that the Liver alone is not able to perform o great a Task, ince the Spleen, Reins, and other parts, are appointed for the ame ue, and ince the Liver erves properly to purge the Blood only from the Bile.

It will not then follow, when the Blood is infected with corrupt Particles, that lip into the Veels which environ the great Guts, that in its paage thro' the Liver, it throws off all its Infection upon that Entral, becaue that Part being only proper to eparate the Bile, 'tis probable that the Corpucles which ininuated themelves into the Veels of the Intetines, being of another Figure than thoe of the Bile, may pas thro' the Liver with the ret of the Blood, without any Stoppage or Separation.
In the econd place we mut conider whether the mall quantity of bad Blood which paes thro' the minute Veels of the Gut Colon, is able to communicate its ill qualities to all the Blood of the Body.

To this econd Difficulty, I anwer, that ince the Blood circulates thro' the whole Body, 'tis plain that a great quantity mut pas in one Day thro' the mallet Veels, and conequently that the Fermentation of the Excrements which are not unfrequently
retain'd eight Days, and ometimes longer, in the great Guts, giving occaion during all that time, to a continual Efflux of Subtil Particles, which are receiv'd into the Pores of the Veels of that Intetine, may in many Circulations corrupt o large a quantity of Blood, that it may in a hort time infect the whole Mas; And by the ame Hypotheis we may give a Natural and Satisfactory Account how the venomous Particles that are darted by a poyonous Inect into one of the Capillary Veels, and that even in the Extremities of the Body, may, in les than an Hour, pread their Infection thro' the whole Mas of the Blood.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Of the Cure or Removal of the Firt immediate Caue of Dieaes, by leening the Quantity of the Blood.
div.p:
THERE are two general ways by which we may leen the quantity of Blood, viz. by preventing its Increae, and by evacuating with all convenient peed, what is already generated: And to anwer thee Indications
there are two great Remedies, viz. Fating and Bleeding.

We may have recoure to the firt, when we perceive ome inconiderable Symptoms of Dieaes that proceed from the exceive quantity of the Blood; in which cae we may content our elves with a very regular Diet, which tho' it has not o quick an Operation as Bleeding, at lat it produces the ame Effect, and that without occaioning any remarkable weaknes; for Abtinence hindering the production of new Blood, does, for the ame reaon, occaion a diipation of part of that which is already generated; and conequently anwers both the Indications that were propos'd.

But if the Dieae requires a peedy Cure, which cannot be perform'd by Abtinence, as it oftentimes happens, we mut have recoure to Bleeding, which by a preent Evacuation of the Blood, detroys the Caue of the approaching Dieae.

'Twou'd be ridiculous to object that Bleeding caues greater Alterations in the Body than Abtinence, or a thin Diet, that it occaions a udden diipation of the Spirits, and conequently is attended with a much greater decay of Strength; for that Los will be much ooner and more eaily repair'd, than the Diorders that are occaion'd by Dieaes.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
Of the ways to remove the Second immediate Caue of Dieaes occaion'd by the too long continuance of the Excrements in the Cavities of the great Guts.
div.p: 'THO the Excrements that are retain'd in the great Guts are meer Impurities, and extremely prejudicial to Health, yet we mut proceed with Caution in the means we ue to expel them.

We mut not begin with the quicket ways, becaue they occaion great Diorders in the Body, and it has been too often oberv'd, that inconiderable Ditempers have been exaperated and confirm'd by an over-haty Cure, and therefore gentle Remedies are both afet and mot uccesful.

Intinct has furnih'd Animals with two ure and effectual Expedients to procure the expulion of the Excrements that are retain'd in the Cavities of the great Guts, viz. Clyters and Purgative Potions, which, 'tis probable Men began to ue when they oberved the great Advantages which Animals receiv'd from them.

Bleeding and Abtinence, which econd the Effects of the former Remedies, are alo Leons which Men owe to the Brutes; and thee four Expedients acting either jointly or eparately, are the afet and mot effectual Means that can be made ue of, to hinder the toppage of the Excrements in the great Guts, and conequently to prevent the Dieaes which proceed from uch Obtructions.

It is eaie to conceive how Abtinence or a regular Diet may contribute to the Evacuation of the Excrements, if we conider that thoe Excrements are the remainders of our Nourihment; That the more we eat and drink, the more Excrements are bred in thoe Parts, o that the Evacuation of thoe Excrements wou'd be an endles Work, if the empty'd Guts were preently fill'd with the uperfluities of a greedy Stomach.
But in the mean time, a Diet which is only precrib'd for prevention, ought not to be o regular or thin as that which is enjoyn'd to ick Perons.

It is known that too nice or paring a Diet is prejudicial to Health, and is o far from aiting Nature in the Evacuation of the Excrements, that it renders her unable to expel 'em. Beides, the Liquor which erves to diolve the Food, not finding Matter to work upon, acts upon the parts that contain and receive it, by drying and conuming them.
It may be further added, that a Man who takes Phyick only for prevention, does not abtain from Labour and Exercie, and therefore tands in need of Nourihment to repair the expence of his Spirits.

Wherefore, to prevent Dieaes, one ought only to fat moderately; at the ame time he ought to avoid as much as he can, eating in Company, becaue People are uually wont to eat a little more than is neceary; and beides, he ought to chue uch Aliments as will leave but few Excrements in the Body; and epecially he mut take care never to eat to atiety.

The econd Expedient we propos'd to facilitate the Paage of the Excrements, is Bleeding, which is doubtles one of the bet Methods that Nature cou'd ugget to Animals; for it is certain, that beides that there is no Remedy which depends more abolutely upon the Pleaure of the Peron who either orders or performs it, o there is none which in mot Caes gives more peedy relief to the Patient.

Every Surgeon knows how ueful Bleeding is to put a top to Defluxions, and the falling down of Humours, which are always apt to fall upon wounded Parts, how effectual it is to diolve large Tumours, with which Wounds are frequently accompany'd; how powerfully it tops the inordinate Flux of Blood in the Wounds of the Veels; and both Surgeons and Midwives know how helpful it is to facilitate o difficult a
Work. Our Buines at preent is to enquire how it may contribute to the Expulion of the Excrements out of the Cavities of the great Guts.

The Expulion of the Excrements retain'd in the Cavities of the great Guts, is perform'd chiefly by the Contraction of its moving Fibres, aited by thoe of the Mucles of the lower Belly, and by the continual Inpiration which obliges the Diaphragma to pres all the Guts. All thee Actions are perform'd by means of the Animal Spirits, which upon uch Occaions flow plentifully to the Parts which are the Organs of thee Actions. Now thee Spirits are continually diipated, and that expence mut be repair'd by the Blood of which they are compos'd, provided there be a reaonable quantity in the Veels which are appointed to contain it; for when there is a Redundancy of Blood, the Spirits are as it were uffocated and drown'd in the abundance of their Matter; o that the bet Office we can do to Nature on uch Occaions, is, by Bleeding, to reduce the Mas of Blood to a moderate quantity, in order to eae her of an unneceary Burthen which obtructs the liberty of her Actions.

Bleeding ought always to precede Purgations when both thee Remedies are indicated by the igns of a Redundancy, exceive Heat, or Corruption of the Blood: For we find by Experience that Purgatives operate both more
gently and effectually, when the Veels are empty'd, and the exceive heat of the Blood allay'd, and its Depravation corrected by Bleeding.

'Tis further obervable, that we ought rather to bleed early in the Morning, than at any other Hour of the Day; and that when we are oblig'd to have recoure to this Remedy in very hot Weather, we ought to be let Blood before the Riing, or after the Setting of the Sun; and in very cold Weather, at Noon: But, in the general, we ought to avoid Bleeding as much as we can, when the Seaon is either exceively hot or cold; for 'tis certain that Bleeding is always attended with better Succes when thee Cautions are oberv'd than when they are neglected,

With repect to the Age of the Patient, we ought to bleed Infants les frequently, and to take les Blood from them than from other Perons, becaue a great part of their Blood is conum'd in the Nourihment and Growth of their Body in all its Dimenions: So that from ix Weeks or two Months after the birth of an Infant, which is the time at which we may begin to let him Blood, if there be a preing Occaion, to the Age of five or ix Years, I wou'd not take away more than from three to ix Ounces of Blood: From ix to ten or twelve Years, you may take ix or eight Ounces: From twelve to fifteen, and o to fifty, you mut
oberve the Signs of Repletion, and the Strength of the Patient, and accordingly you may take away from nine to twelve or fifteen Ounces of Blood.

After fifty Years of Age, we mut be more cautious and moderate both as to the frequency of Bleeding, and the quantity of Blood we take away, for fear of cauing too great a diipation of the Spirits, which from that Age to extreme old Age are daily decaying both in Quantity and Quality.

The viible Signs of a Redundancy of Blood in the Veels, are the large or frequent Evacuations of it by the Noe, or other parts of the Body, the welling or ditenion of the Veins, Boils, Pimples, or other Eruptions, frequent Ebullitions or Fluhings towards the Skin, Eryipela's, Inflammations of the Eyes and Throat, a continual deire to Sleep, and a Wearines and Heavines of the whole Body, not occaion'd by any Labour or violent Exercie.

When you perceive all, or mot of thoe Symptoms, and when they continue for ome time, you mut immediately open a Vein, and take away a large quantity of Blood; for the uperfluous Blood which is not employ'd in the Nourihment of the Body if it be not evacuated, will oon putrefy, and occaion a Fever, Obtructions in the mall Paages of the Intetines, or an Accumulation of Humours in ome part of the Body.

In fine, that we may make right ue of Bleeding, we ought to conider how the Patient uually bears it; for thoe who undergo it eaily, may be let Blood oftener, and more plentifully than thoe who cannot bear it without trouble and difficulty. Thus one who commonly finds himelf weak or faint after Bleeding, ought rather to Bleed twice, and in mall quantities, than to put himelf in danger of fainting or wooning away, by a large Evacuation: For 'tis certain that Fainting and Swooning do extremely diturb the whole Oeconomy of the Body, notwithtanding the ridiculous Opinion of thoe who imagine that Bleeding can never be effectual, unles it be continu'd till the Patient faint away.

Bleeding without neceity, that is, when there is no Superfluity to be voided, no exces of Heat to be allay'd, and no Putrefaction to be corrected, robs Nature of the pure Blood, which is neceary for the Nourihment of the Body, and the production of Spirits, which are the principal Intruments of the Soul in all its Actions. 'Tis plain from hence, that after uch unneceary Evacuations, Nature acts lowly and feebly, that the Entrails are heated, and that all the Parts are dry'd up, which makes way for a long Train of Dieaes. It is not therefore pertinent to ue Remedies at all times for the preervation of our Health: But 'tis neceary before we take 'em, that our Intinct hall let us know the neceity of 'em by the preages of ome future Ditemper.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
Of the Signs by which Intinct makes every particular Peron foreee mot of his Dieaes.
div.p: THE mot uual Symptoms of an approaching Ditemper, are a Wearines and Heavines of all the Body, without having been fatigu'd by any violent Exercies.
A Yellownes all over the Body.
An Eryipela, or Ulceration all over the Skin.
The Itch or Scab.
Boils or Inflammations in divers parts.
A udden pining away, or leannes of all the Body, and of the Face.
Wandering and frequent Rheumatical Pains, accompany'd with irregular Shiverings.
An almot continual deire to Sleep, but chiefly after Eating; or, on the other hand want of Sleep, or an interruption of Sleep by frightful Dreams and vain Fears.
An unaccountable Dulnes and Melancholy, which will not give way to any ort of Pleaure.
Nocturnal Sweating.
Frequent Pains of the Head, Vertigo's, and a Numnes of the Part when one puts on his Hat.
A Rednes all over the Face.
A languihing and inking, or an unuual hining of the Eyes, a Tincture of Yellow or Black on the Eye-lids.
Bleeding at the Noe, or any other Part of the Body.
A Singing or Hiing Noie in the Ears.
Rednes or Drynes of the Cheeks and Lips.
Yawning, and involuntary Sighs.
Little Whitih Ulcers on the Palate, and in all the inide of the Mouth.
The Clammines or Foulnes of the Tongue.
Drynes of the Throat, epecially in the Morning; unles the exces of the foregoing Day be the caue of it.
Kernels about the Ears, Necks, and Arm-Pits; and painful Tumours in the Groyne.
Stinking Breath, not proceeding from any Corruption of the Teeth, or from any Ulcer or Impotume in the Mouth.
Los of Appetite, or a riing of the Stomach againt Meat.
Vomitting of weet, bitter, or alt Water, epecially in a Morning.
Rheums or Defluxions, a Cough and Difficulty of Breathing, without a harp Pain of the Breat, but rather proceeding from Oppreion or Stoppage.
A Hardnes and Heavines in the Stomach, as if it were a great Stone; and a troubleome Senation, as if the Belly were queez'd with a Cros-Bar.
Piles or Emerods of long continuance and painful.
Great Heat in the Palms of the Hands.
A Swelling of the Veins in the Face, and in all the Extremities of the Body.

All thee Symptoms, and many others, of which every one may have had Experience, are o many igns to give us notice that our Health is in danger of yielding to the Inults of a Dieae, if we do not take care to upport it.

The Inquiry wou'd be more curious than neceary, to examine for what Reaons thoe Symptoms give us notice of approaching Ditempers; for as it is ufficient for a Pilot to have a Needle touch'd with a Load-Stone, and to know that it turns always towards a certain Pole, without being oblig'd to know the natural Caue of o urprizing a Phaenomenon, o 'tis alo enough for any Body to know that the igns of which we have poken, are o many Fore-runners of Ditempers, without troubling himelf to examine particularly why every one of thee Symptoms is an effect of this general Caue;
wherefore we are forewarn'd ometimes by ome of them, and ometimes by others; ometimes by one alone, and ometimes by many: But it being generally known that one or many of 'em, or this and that Symptom, are certain Marks of a Depravation of the Health, we may chue either to wait till the Dieae appears, and afterwards cure it with difficulty, or to prevent it eaily before it is form'd: Now 'tis mot certain that a Man hou'd rather be his own Phyician, while the Dieae is yet unform'd, than to wait till it appear, that he may avoid fallling into thoe Extremities to which it may reduce the toutet Heart, by exces of Pain, impatient uneaines under the Cure, and perpetual fear of Death.

From this Principle we may infer that 'tis not only unneceary, but even dangerous to take Phyick when we are not troubl'd with any of thoe Symptoms, becaue nothing that is able to caue an Alteration in the Body can be taken without making ome Impreion on it, either good or bad: For Example; the Food which we take in too great a quantity, or which is of hard Digetion, engenders a great quantity of Crudities and Excrements, which are, as we have already intimated, the Caue of mot Dieaes.

Purgative Medicines taken without neceity, drive the ueful Liquors or Juices towards the places where they are expell'd, and not finding any that are uperfluous or
deprav'd, weakens the Fibres of the Intetines, Veins, and Arteries, by unneceary Irritations, and produces an unuual Heat in the whole Body.

When we are forewarn'd of Dieaes, either the Symptoms are many and preing, or few and inconiderable: When they are many and our Intinct eems to redouble its Admonitions, we mut loe no time, but without having regard either to the Seaon of the Year, the Age of the Moon, or the Temperature of the Air, take uch Phyick as we think neceary to preerve us from falling into any Dieae. But if thee Symptoms are but mall, and few in Number, ince we know by Experience that Purgatives work more mildly and eaily in a Temperate Seaon, as in the Spring and Harvet, than during the exceive Heat of the Summer, and great Cold of the Winter; when the Moon is in her Wane or Declination, than during her Increae; in Dry rather than Moit Weather, and that they weaken the Body much more in the Dog-Days, the Soltices and Equinoxes, than at other times; we may defer the ue of Phyick for ome Days, that we may take it at a time when all thoe Circumtances, or mot of them will be in a condition to make it ucceed the better.

'Tis commonly believ'd that only weak and ickly Perons ought to take care to preerve their Health, that thoe who are of a trong
or healthy Contitution, ought not to trouble themelves about it, becaue Nature can in trong Bodies remove and detroy, by its own Force, the Caues of all their Ditempers; and becaue Phyick diturbs the Oeconomy of our Body much more than it is of ue to upport it; ince we ee by Experience that mot of thoe imaginary ick Perons, who pend all their time in the Preervation of their Health, die ooner than thoe who never have recoure to Phyick but when they are abolutely forc'd thereto by ome preing Ditemper. I know that it is dangerous to be too fond of Medicines, that is, either to take too much, or too often; but I may venture to affirm, that there is no Man, let him be never o trong and healthy, but has ometimes need of the help of Phyick; for as the bet Water in the World leaves always ome Dregs in the Pipes thro' which it paes, which gathering inenibly, Obliges thoe who tand in need of the Water, to cleane the Pipes, and to hinder their being quite topt; o it is certain that the bet Blood that can be imagin'd to flow in a perfectly ound Body, will leave ome Dregs and Filth in the Veels thro' which it paes to all the Parts of the Body: And thee Dregs gathering by degrees in the Veels, hinders the free Motion of the Blood, the interruption of which occaions thoe premonitory Diorders which we call Preages of Intinct; and in this Cae 'tis plain we ought
to take Phyick to prevent Sicknes: For it happens at lat, that mot of thoe obtinate People, who depie all orts of Remedies under pretext of the healthines of their Contitution, are attack'd with Dieaes which are o much the more troubleome and dangerous, as their Health eem'd to be perfect; o that oftentimes their Averion to Phyick cots 'em their Life. And tho' they ecape, they mut expect to uffer all the Incommodities of a tedious languihing Ditemper, and will never be able to recover what they have lot.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Of Clyters and Medicines.
div.p: AS for the way of purging by Clyters, 'tis certain that they may be us'd at all times when we find any Symptoms of the Stoppage or retention of the Excrements in the great Guts; for it being impoible to make thee Injections acend higher than the Intetine call'd Caecum, becaue of the Obtacles they meet with there, they cannot be uppos'd to occaion a great Irritation in that Paage, whoe Structure is not o ine as that of the mall Guts, unles they be impregnated with very violent Purgatives.

We mut not make the taking of Clyters a etl'd Practice or Cutom, as many People do, who wou'd fanie themelves ick if they hou'd omit 'em two Days; for the too frequent ue of Clyters, makes Nature lazy, and the lazines of Nature is the fatal Caue of many Dieaes.

Yet I will not pretend to cenure thoe who bleed and purge contantly in the Spring and in Autumn, epecially if they be young, vigorous, and of a full Body, if they eat much, or live a edentary Life, without Motion or Exercie, or if they are already habituated to that Cutom; for it is certain that many Dieaes may be prevented by this means, and that one expoeth himelf almot infallibly to very dangerous Ditempers, by interrupting this practice after he has once accutom'd himelf thereto.

It may alo be proper to take Phyick after a long Journey, or extraordinary Labour; and, to conclude, we ought always to purge once a Year, if our Intinct dicovers any Symptoms of a future Dieae; for thereby we may prevent the great Collection of Excrements in the great Guts, where they are always apt to tick, unles they be expell'd by the irritation occaion'd by purging Remedies.

div.head: CHAP. X.
Of the way of uing Medicines in Order to the Preervation of Health.
div.p: SINCE Health is no les preerv'd by the right ue of Meat and Drink than by Medicines that are able to remove the Caues of our Ditempers, the Reader mut remember what we hinted about Diet, that we mut avoid all manner of Exces, and abtain from all orts of crude Aliments, and uch as are apt either to make the Belly too looe or too cotive; that every Man is able to make a right choice and Judgment of the Medicines that are mot proper for him, and that after he has found ome that are agreeable to thoe Rules, he ought to prefer them before any Remedies that may be recommended to him by others.

I will not repeat what I have already aid about Diet, or the ue of Aliments, which do not deerve the Name of Medicines, but briefly conider the two general ways of attaining to Health, viz. Bleeding and Purging.

And ince I have alo deliver'd my Opinion concerning Bleeding, and the Rules that
ought to be oberv'd in that cae, I hall content my elf with referring the Reader to what I have already aid on that Subject, and only treat of the ue of Laxatives, or Purging Medicines.
'Tho' the Purgatives of which Clyters are compos'd, cannot much diorder the Body, yet there are ome Meaures to be taken in order to the right ue of thee Remedies.

Firt, they ought to precede the ue of uch Purgatives as are to be taken by the Mouth, becaue they facilitate their Operation by procuring the Expulion of the Excrements that are retain'd in the great Guts, which wou'd oppoe their Paage, and that of the Excrementitious Humours which they draw from the Stomach, mall Guts, Veins and Arteries; for as in a Woodmonger's-Yard when People come to buy Wood for Fuel, when one Pile is old, and the Woodmonger deigns to sell another, ince it wou'd be a needles trouble to climb up to the top of the Pile to erve every ingle Cutomer, he overturns the whole Pile, by drawing out five or ix pieces of Wood at the bottom; the ame effect is produc'd by Clyters, which, by voiding the greatet part of the Excrements and Filth retain'd in the Cells of the Intetines, facilitate the Operation of purging Potions, which finding the Paage free, are eaily able to carry off the Matter they have queez'd out of the Arteries, and the limy and gros Humours which they bring from the
Stomach, and from the mall Guts, and beides, expel the ret of the Gros Excrements which they find lodg'd in the Cells of the great Guts.

We mut further oberve, that the Operation of Clyters is very irregular; for in ome Perons a Clyter of Oxycrate will procure wonderful Evacuations, which in others wou'd be altogether unprofitable; and in ome the tronget Clyters will not produce the leat effect: And that which operates well at one time, will not work at all at another; wherefore we mut learn to prepare everal orts, oberving, nevertheles, to chue always uch as are mild and imple rather than uch as are violent, and hard to be prepar'd.

As for Purgatives that are taken by the Mouth, 'tis better to take them by way of Infuion than in Subtance, that we may pare the parts thro' which they mut pas, a double Labour; for beides, that they mut uffer the Operation of the Medicines that are taken in Subtance, they mut alo unfold and dientangle the Particles in which their Purgative Vertue conits, from many others of which they are compos'd; whereas the Liquor in which they are infus'd, imbibes only their Purgative Particles, and, by reaon of its fluidity, infinuates it elf more eaily into the mall Paages of the Body, than the gros Subtance can be uppos'd to do.
In order to the right ue of thee Medicines, there are four Obervations to be made.

The Firt is, to take 'em by degrees, that is, to begin with the mot Mild and Simple: But if their Weaknes hinder their Operation, we mut augment the Doe, or take a tronger Medicine, till uch time as the Evacuation be made proportionable to the Symptoms we perceive of a greater or maller fulnes or redundancy of Humours.

The Second Obervation concerns the quicknes of their Paage, which is of great importance, becaue they cannot remain long in the Body without occaioning a violent Irritation of the parts they touch, which may be attended with very dangerous Conequences; for a purging Medicine has almot the ame Operation on the parts of the Body thro' which it paes, as a Spur has upon a Hore; becaue as the Hore goes fater when the Rider purs him but once, and kicks and winces when he keeps the Spur contantly in his Sides, o the Purgative by its firt Irritations, moves the Parts thro' which 'tis carry'd, to expel the Excrements that are contain'd in 'em; but when it tays too long, it enflames the Parts, and renders the Humours hot and dry, and conequently unfit for Evacuation; o that its Operation is both inconiderable, and extremely troubleome to the Patient.

To avoid this Inconveniency in the ue of Laxatives, they ought always to be accompany'd with ome Vehicle, that is to ay, a Subtance fit to ininuate it elf into the cloet parts of the Body, notwithtanding all the Obtructions it may meet with in the Parts that are appropriated for eparating the Humours, as the Liver, Spleen, Pancreas, and all the Entrals.

Thee Vehicles may be made of Decoctions impregnated with the ubtil Parts of certain Plants that are proper to lip into the mallet Pores of the Capillary Veels, as are, for Example, the Decoctions of the Roots of wild Succory, Strawberry-Leaves, Dog-Gras, Agrimony, Sorrel, Chervil, and many other Herbs which are endu'd with the ame Virtues.

Intead of thee Decoctions, you may ue the Juice of a Limon, or Orange, Verjuice, White-Wine, Whey, and many other Remedies, which every one may chue from his own private Experience, to facilitate the Operation of Purgatives.

The Third Rule to be oberv'd in the ue of purging Medicines, is, to chue uch as do not make you cotive after the ue of 'em; for this is the uret Mark that the Phyick is proportionated to the Strength of the Patient on whom it works, epecially ince 'tis but too frequently confirm'd by Experience, that the more violent the Medicines are, the Patient is the more cotive after the ue of
them. One might inferr from hence, that the ame thing happens on thee Occaions to the moving Fibres of the Intetines, as to Perons who being forc'd to undergo involuntary Labour, are o wearied and jaded with their forc'd Exercie, that they work no longer than while the Rod is over their Heads; o the Fibres of the Intetines having been too roughly and frequently haken by the Operation of the Medicine, are o weary'd with thee forc'd Contractions, that they cannot afterwards perform the Motions that are neceary for the Expulion of the Excrements which gather daily in their Cavities; o that we are obliged either to accutom our elves to Phyick, or, if we neglect to ue it, mut expect a new Accumulation of Excrements, which will oon after be the Caue of a new Dieae.

To conclude; The lat Obervation in the ue of Purgatives relates particularly to thoe weak Medicines that produce little or no Effect, when they are often repeated in a little time; for the moving Fibres of the Intetines are oon accutom'd to the Impreion of uch Remedies, and become perfectly inenible of uch feeble Irritations: Jut as the Organs of the Senes are not enible of the Impreion of thee Objects to which they are accutom'd. In this cae we mut change the Remedies, becaue even the weaket Purgatives remaining in the Body, cannot but occaion ome diturbance in it.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Of Purgatives, and how they operate: Of the Time and Manner of uing them.
div.p: IT is certain that the Operation of Purgatives detroys the mot immediate Caues of the greatet part of our Dieaes, whether they be taken inwardly, or injected by way of Clyters.

However, it mut be acknowledg'd, that the way of adminitring 'em occaions ome difference in their Operation; for ince Clyters reach no further than the great Guts, they can only facilitate the Evacuation of the Excrements that are retain'd in thoe Intetines; whereas, when they are taken inwardly, they not only caue the ame Irritations in all the Parts which they touch, and conequently by augmenting their Natural Motion, haten the expulion of the Matter which they contain; but many of their Particles mingle with the Chyle in the Veels which carry it to the Heart, in which, as well as in the Arteries, they excite divers Fermentations, that promote the eparation of the different Particles of the Blood, in the everal Parts of the Body where they are
uually eparated from its Mas, according to the dipoition that each of thoe Remedies has, to put certain parts of the Blood in Motion, rather than others.

Thus we may oberve that a viible Fermentation or Ebullition is produc'd in certain Liquors, when they are mix'd with other Fluids that are dipos'd to put 'em in Motion, whereas they remain unditurb'd when they are mixt with others.

And from the Operation of Purgatives on different parts of the Blood, there aries a ditinction of Names: For Example; ome are call'd imply Purgatives, which are again divided into Hydragogues, Cholagogues, Melanagogues, and Phlegmagogues; or Medicines that purge Watery Humours, Choler, Melancholy, and Phlegm: Others are call'd Emeties, Sudorifics, Errhines, &c. Now thoe Names are very fitly impos'd, either with repect to the Parts of the Body thro' which they procure the Evacuations, or to the parts of the Blood which they are particularly apt to put in Motion.

From hence we may oberve, that all thoe Remedies are endu'd with one common Property, that is, to excite a Motion in the Blood; and that their different ways of Operating proceed only from the different Figure or Contexture of their Parts; for by reaon of their peculiar Configuration, they are more eaily admitted into certain parts of the Body than into others, and by the
Irritation they occaion in the Parts, they promote the Separation which is perform'd there, of ome particular Excrements from the Blood. And upon this Score we may reaonably ay, that they are proper to purge uch and uch Parts; as for Example, uch as are proper to purge the Liver, we call Hepatics; and thoe that are peculiarly adapted to the Spleen, are term'd Splenetics.

Beides, according to the various ituation or contexture of their Parts, they are dipoed to agitate Certain Particles of the Blood, to which they unite ooner than to others: And upon this account we may ay that uch a Medicine is proper to purge uch a Humour.

This Obervation is confirm'd by Experience, particularly what relates to Hydragogues, or Medicines that purge Watery Humours; for the Evacuation of Seroities is much more enible than that of the other Particles which compoe the Blood, becaue that which the Purgative drives into the Intetines, whether it be eparated by the Glands of their inward Membrane, or queez'd out of the Biliary and Pancreatic Ducts, being mixt with the Slime and Excrements which it finds in the Intetines, it is very hard to determine what Humour hath been chiefly wrought upon or expell'd by the Purgative Medicine.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
Of the Purgatives that ought to be ued for the preventing of Dieaes.
div.p: PRGATION by Stool ought to be preferr'd before all other Evacuations, becaue 'tis the mot natural and ordinary way, and that which bet anwers the deign we ought to have in order to the removal of the Caue of Dieaes, peedily to expel the Excrements that are topt in the great Guts, and to correct the ill Quality of the Blood, which is the Conequence thereof.

Nevertheles Emetics or Vomits may be ueful to ome Perons when they are troubl'd with an inclination to Vomit, uch as thoe who have a trong and large Breat. And others may profitably ue Sudorifics, namely, thoe who are Choleric, and whoe Pores are very open. Diuretics, or Medicines that provoke Urine, are proper for thoe who feel a heavines and heat in their Kidneys, uch as are ubject to the Gravel, live unmarried, and abtain from the ue of Women.
Some may make ue of uch as occaion Spitting, and others of thoe which expel the Excrements by the Noe.

Thoe who have a weak Breat, and wet Brain, may find benefit by the ue of thee Remedies, provided they have no Polypus, or other Impediment in the Notrils. In a Word, every Man ought to be directed by his own Experience, and either have recoure to, or abtain from uch orts of Evacuations, according to the good or bad Effects which he finds they produce upon him.

For Example; a Peron who is apt to Vomit without any coniderable trouble, when he finds his Stomach over-charg'd, will receive greater benefit by a Vomit than by ordinary Purgations; whereas thoe who cannot Vomit without an unuual diturbance, ought rather to ue Simple Laxatives, leat the Fibres of the Stomach be weaken'd by uch over-violent Motions.

Others who labour under Faintnes or Wearines, provided they be not naturally too dry or lean, will find themelves eaed if after Bleeding they take a Medicine to procure a moderate Sweat. The People in the Levant by this means prevent a great number of Dieaes.

Thoe who are troubl'd with Pains in their Kidneys, and whoe Urine is of a high Colour, or thick, may, after the ue of cooling Remedies, have recoure to Medicines that provoke Urine, either alone, or mixed with Laxatives.
Thoe who are naturally inclin'd to Spitting, and have a moit Brain, may both prevent and cure their Ditempers by raiing a Salivation by the ue of Remedies that are proper to produce that Effect.
In fine, every Man ought to conult his own Experience, and tudy the Contitution of his Body; and afterwards ue thoe Remedies which he finds to be mot ueful and agreeable to him.

There is one important Rule to be oberv'd in the adminitring of all thoe Remedies, and that is, To begin always with the gentlet and mot imple. It is certain that when we ue Remedies meerly for prevention, we ought to be our own Phyicians; for ince the bare Preages or Signs of a future Dieae cannot be uppos'd to have depriv'd us of the ue of our Reaon, we may chue thoe Medicines which upon trial have formerly ucceeded, and which cannot be o well known by a Stranger as by our elves.
Beides, it ought to be oberv'd, that there is nothing more various or uncertain than the Operation of Purgatives on Humane Bodies.

Some Perons are violently purg'd by weak Medicines, when a tronger Remedy wou'd not produce the leat effect upon 'em: There are others on whom mild Phyick will not work at all, and even the tronget Medicines are carce effectual: On the other hand, ome are o eaily purg'd, that a Decoction
of Herbs will uffice; and to others half an Hours Converation in an Apothecary's Shop: Some are purg'd by Strawberries, Cherries, Gooeberries, Peaches, Pears, &c. Some by our Milk, freh Pork, &c. and others by a moderate Entertainment with jovial Companions; for Mirth contributes as much to the Paage of the Excrements, as Melancholy or Sadnes does to their Stoppage in the Guts.
Some are purg'd by a imple cooling Decoction when they begin firt to drink it; and in others Clyters produce a plentiful Evacuation, tho' they are hardly mov'd by internal Medicines.

To conclude; there is nothing les regular than the Operation of Purges on different Bodies; and it is impoible for the mot expert Phyician in the World to dicover this variety in every particular Peron: And therefore, as I intimated before, we ought to tudy our elves, that we may be able to chue out of o great a number of Remedies that have been often try'd, thoe that are mot agreeable to our Bodies.
The gentlet Purges, and thoe that are mot agreeable to our Contution, are of two orts, viz. ome are brought to us from Forreign Countries, aud others grow in our own Climate.

The afet foreign Purgatives are Senna, Caia, Tamarinds, Rubarb, Manna, &c. and the mildet that grow in our own Climate are Roes, Peach-Flowers, Violets, our Garden Ruburb,
the great and mall Centory, Briony, Aarabacca, Mint, Bawm, Spanih Broom, Thyme, Polypody of the Oak, Black Maiden-Hair, Ceterach, Wall Rue, Betony, Lettice, Purlane, Sorrel, Chervil, Black Hellebore, the Tops of Hops, the Yellow-flower'd Flagg or Flowerde-Luce, the Bark of Elder, the Black Plum or Prune, Wallwort, wild Cucumbers, and many other Plants. You may pres out the Juice of thee Herbs, or infue 'em, or make 'em up into Powders, Syrups, Conerves, Tablets, Pills, Troches, or any other Form whatoever.

Beides, tho' I prefer imple Remedies before uch as are compounded, I do not pretend to blame the ue of certain Mixtures that are common in Pharmacy; for the Addition of Sugar, or ome other uch Ingredient, cannot take away the Vertue of the Simples.
In the mean time, 'tis certain that we ought to abtain from all violent Remedies, epecially Chymical Preparations, when we only take Phyick for prevention.

I am peruaded that the mot Simple Remedies are the bet, and that all the Secret lies in the right ue of them; for as the Colours upon a Painter's Pallet are of themelves only fit to make a confus'd and diagreeable Mixture, o Medicines, epecially Purgatives, are in their own Nature only fit to weaken the Patient, and to caue a violent Motion in his Blood: But, on the other hand, as
the ame Colours placed upon a Cloth by an Ingenious Painter, make a very valuable and beautiful Picture, o the ame Remedies, tho they are contrary to Nature when miapply'd, may ait her to overcome a Ditemper when they are rightly adminiter'd.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
The Solution of certain Difficulties that deter mot Perons from making ue of Purging Remedies for the preventing of Ditempers.
div.p: THOSE who refue to admit of Purgagatives, excue their Obtinacy by one of thoe three Reaons which hall be propos'd and anwer'd in this Chapter.

div.head: OBJECT. I.
Againt Clyters and Purges:
div.p: YOU advie me, Sir, ays one to his Phyician, to take a Clyter, or a Purging Medicine, but I have no occaion for uch Remedies; I go daily and regularly to tool, and why hou'd I be tormented with Clyters and Purgatives?

I anwer, That tho a Man goes daily and regularly to tool, yet it does not follow that he ought to be exempted from Purgation either by Clyters and Medicines, ince 'tis frequently oberv'd that thoe who go naturally to tool every Day, do, notwithtanding, perceive by the above-mention'd Symptoms, that there are ome Excrements left behind in thoe Paages which erve for their Expulion: Now 'tis plain that their Excrements mut be evacuated, to prevent the Dieaes that proceed from the Corruption of thee Impurities.
If any Peron deire to be atisfy'd how when a Man goes daily and regularly to tool, any Excrements can remain in the great Guts;

The Anwer is eaie, if we remember what has been already aid of the Structure of the great Intetines, the Parts of which are as it were o many Bags or Cavities faten'd at certain ditances to thoe Intetines. Now 'tis ufficient for the Paage of the greatet part of the Excrements which are eparated from our daily Nourihment that the middle Part of the Gut be open and free; but in the mean time, ome of the Excrements may lip into the bottom of thoe Cells or Bags, and by degrees fill up their Cavity; o that at lat the middle Paage may be almot entirely topt by thoe ditended Bags; and 'tis then that we perceive the Signs of an unuual Load and Obtruction in thoe Parts.

This Doctrine may be further illutrated by comparing thee Obtructions in the great Gut to the Stoppages that happen frequently in the Conduits that are made to convey the Filth from our Streets; for the Dirt ticks by degrees to the ides of the Pipes, and fills up all the Holes and Cavities it meets with, tho' it does not immediately hinder even ome of the thicket Mud to lip away; o that unles they be ometimes cour'd by a pretty violent Shower, that may force a great quantity of Water into the Cavities of the Pipes, and by the Rapidity of its Current, carry off the Filth; they mut be open'd from time to time, and the tagnant Dirt looen'd, and driven forwards into the Common Sink, by the help of Convenient Intruments.

The ame Obervation may be apply'd to the great Guts, both with repect to the Excrements that are detain'd in its Cells, and which pas daily through its Cavity; for when a great quantity of em is gather'd in thee Bags or Cells, and begin to corrupt there, the preure of thee ditended Cells upon the neighbouring Parts, and the corrupted Corpucles which lip into the Veels that environ them, produce the Symptoms of an approaching Indipoition tho a coniderable part of our daily Nourihment having till a free Paage through the Cavity of the Gut, may furnih ufficient Matter for Stools. 'Tis plain then, that we have need
of Clyters and purging Medicines, to draw the Excrements out of the places where they are topt; and that conequently tho' we go to tool naturally every Day, we may ometimes tand in need of an artificial Evacuation.

div.head: OBJECT. II.
div.p: ANother will perhaps be apt to ay, You order me a Clyter, or a purging Medicine, tho' I have not tated any ort of Nourihment thee four or five Days: how can there be any Matter left to be evacuated in a Body o empty as mine mut be after o long an Abtinence?

But this eeming Difficulty may be very eaily anwer'd, for when a Man for ome Days has been troubl'd with a contant Averion to all orts of Nourihment, 'tis an evident ign that there is a great Collection of Impurities in the place where we have made it appear that they are uually apt to top. Nor will it appear trange that a Peron hould loe his Appetite when the bottom of the Stomach is drawn downwards by uch a Load of Excrements, if we conider that the unuual weight that hangs like a Clog upon the Stomach, may be reaonably uppos'd to produce the ame Effect upon it as if it were fill'd with a hearty Meal.

So when we advie a Man in that condition to take Phyick, our deign is not to evacuate the remainder of his Meat, ince we uppoe he has fated for ome Days, but to procure the evacuation of thoe Impurities which being inenibly topt and gather'd in thoe parts, wou'd otherwie occaion thoe Diorders in the Body, of which I have already dicours'd.

div.head: OBJECT. III.
div.p: ONE that is troubl'd with a Looenes will perhaps be extremely urpriz'd when he is order'd to take a Clyter, or a purging Medicine, and will be ready to look upon that advice as a ure way to encreae his Ditemper, which in his opinion has purg'd him but too thoroughly already, without the aitance of Phyick.

This Objection will appear as groundles as either of the former, if it be conider'd that a Looenes is uually either the effect of Indigetion, in which cae it ceaes after ome time, and hardly requires the ue of Remedies; or 'tis a ign that the Excrements are topt in the great Guts, and then if there be a copious Evacuation, we mut recruit Nature, and repair her decay'd Vigour, by good Nourihment taken in mall Quantities: On the other hand, if the flux be inconiderable,
or if the Patient be frequently troubl'd with a deire to go to Stool, without voiding any thing, ince 'tis evident from thence, that the Motion of the Intetines is not ufficient to expel thoe Impurities that caue uch frequent Irritations, we mut in the firt place by the ue of Clyters endeavour to diolve that corrupt and biting Matter; and afterwards when the Irritation ceaes, we mut take ome Purgative Medicine to expel the remainder of that excrementitious Matter that may be lodg'd in ome places, which the Clyters cou'd not reach.

div.head: OBJECT. IV.
Againt Bleeding.
