div.p: 'TIS the uual Cant of thoe who are profet Enemies to Bleeding, that the Blood is the Treaure of Life, and conequently that we ought rather to furnih the enfeebl'd Patient with a freh upply of that precious Liquor, than to rob him of what he is already poet of.

But I mut beg thoe Gentlemen's leave to put 'em in mind, that the Blood can never deerve o noble a Title if it be either deprav'd or redundant: For if it exceeds either in Quantity or Quality, it is o far
from preerving our Health, that it expoes us to the mot dangerous Ditempers.

As our Life is manifetly endanger'd when too large a quantity of Blood is lot, o it is ecur'd and upported when a moderate quantity of impure and corrupt Blood is taken away; however, it mut be acknowledg'd that this Evacuation ought always to be perform'd with a great deal of Caution, according to the Age and Strength of the Patient, the Nature of his Dieae, and the Seaons of the Year.

And therefore thoe who are deirous to be their own Phyicians, ought to try eveveral Remedies, and to make choice of uch as produce the ame Effects upon them which in the foregoing Chapters are acrib'd to afe and ueful Remedies.
A TREATISE OF Particular Remedies.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
WHen I form'd the Deign of publihing the preceding Treatie, I did not intend to have added a Collection of particular Remedies, becaue I look'd upon that as a Subject that had been ufficiently handl'd, and even almot wholly exhauted by o many Authors who have compos'd entire Volumes of this Nature. But ince I have been deir'd by everal Perons whom I wou'd not willingly dioblige, to compleat
my ndertaking by ubjoining an account of uch Remedies as I had oberv'd to be mot eteem'd, and found to be mot ueful and effectual, I cou'd not deny 'em o mall a Favour. And that I might render my Performance in this kind more erviceable to the Public, I thought fit to add ome hort Reflexions, according to the variety of the Subject.

div.head: A TREATISE CONTAINING An Account of the mot Simple Remedies, and uch as are mot frequently ued for the curing of everal Dieaes.
Of Medicines in General.
div.p: MEDICINES or Remedies are mix'd Bodies, which, being taken by the Mouth, if they are Internal, or applied outwardly, if External, erve to retore our Health, by altering the bad Dipoition of our Bodies. They differ both from our uual Food, and from Poyon; the firt of which preerves and upports our Health, and the latter detroys it.

We ought not to have recoure to Purgatives unles the Intetines be tuff'd with clammy and thick Humours, or the Mas of
the Blood be full of alt or bulky Particles, that hinder its Circulation, which may be known by a Hardnes or Swelling of the Belly, Drowines, Wearines, &c. 'Tis expedient to make ue of Clyters ome Days before Purgation, that the purging Medicine not meeting with any Obtacles, may operate more trongly and quickly, and occaion les diturbance in the Body.

An Ounce, or an Ounce and a half of extracted Caia diolv'd in a Glas of Whey, or mixed with an equal quantity of compound Syrup of Apples, moitens and cools the Body, looens the thick Humours that are lodg'd in the Breat, and helps one to Spit freely.

Feeble and weak Perons, uch as thoe who are extremely lean, whom we uually call Phthiical or Conumptive, as alo Women with Child, may be afely purg'd with an Ounce or two of Manna, taken in Veal or Chicken-Broath. When we deign to purge, cour and wah away the limy Matter that ticks in the Intetines, we may profitably ue the Juice of Roes, from one Ounce to two. And 'tis alo a good Remedy for a Looenes.

Rhubarb taken in Subtance, from half a Dram to a Dram, purges Choler, helps thoe that are troubl'd with a Looenes, and erves to kill Worms. It may be alo us'd by way of Infuion, from a Dram to half an Ounce, according to the Age and Strength of the Patient.
To evacuate Hydropical Humours, or bring down Women's Monthly Coures, we may ue the Root of Briony, from half a Dram to a Dram, or its Juice to half an Ounce.

I will not peak of Agaric, Scammony, Jalap, Mirabolans, and Mechoacan, becaue they operate too violently; nor will I trouble the Reader with an Account of Chymical Medicines, which ought not to be ued but with a great deal of Precaution, nor without the Advice of a Phyician.

div.head: Of Diuretics.
div.p: DIureticks erve to augment the eroity or fluidity of the Blood, to agitate the Serous, and coagulate the Fibrous Part, and to retard the Coure of the Humours.

We ought never to ue them without an antecedent preparation of the Body by Purgation, leat the gros Particles which they agitate, and drive towards the Reins, hou'd breed an Obtruction in thoe Parts, and occaion a toppage of Urine.
River-Water, Mineral-Waters, and White-Wine, are the mildet opening Medicines we have.

The Five great opening Roots, viz. Aparagus, Fennel, Parley, Smallage, and Butcher's-Broom, provoke Urine, and even ometimes procure Sweating; but I hou'd rather chue to make ue of thoe which are call'd the leer opening Roots, becaue they do not occaion
o great an agitation in the Blood, and conequently open a freer Paage to the Serous and Saline Particles. Thoe Roots are Dogs-Gras, Capers, Eringo, Madder, and Retharrow. You may prepare a Decoction of 'em, adding, if you pleae, a ufficient quantity of Sal Prunellae.
A Spoonful of the Juice of Roes in a little Spanih Wine, or in two or three Spoonfuls of Brandy, is alo a very good Remedy for the Colic, occaion'd by the Pain of the Kidneys.
A Simple Bath of lukewarm Water is Diuretical, becaue it dilates the Paages of the Urine, and augments the Seroity of the Blood.

div.head: Of Emeticks or Vomits.
div.p: VOmitting is a contraction of the Fibres of the Stomach, by which the Matter contain'd in that Part is forc'd upwards thro' the Oeophagus or Gullet.

Emeticks may be profitably ued when the Stomach is burden'd with ill-digeted Food, or full of corrupt Humours, in which cae we are troubl'd with an averion to Meat, frequent Reachings, Bitternes in the Mouth, Dimnes of Sight, and ometimes with a Lienteria, that is, when we void what we eat or Drink by Stool, without any igns of Digetion.
Melancholic or Phthiical Perons ought to abtain from the ue of thee Remedies, and likewie Women with Child, unles in ome caes to haten their Delivery.
A large Draught of warm Water proves Emetic to thoe who are naturally enclin'd to Vomiting, becaue it lackens the Fibres of the Stomach, and agitates the Saline Particles that are lodg'd in it.

Aarabacca taken in Subtance, from half a Dram to a Dram, provokes Vomiting; but if it be infus'd in Wine, you may take from one Dram to three. Black Hellebore taken from four to eight Grains, purges upwards and downwards omewhat violently; and, according to the Opinion of Paracelus, cures the Apoplexy, Gout, Dropie, and Epilepie.

div.head: Of Sudorifics and Diaphoretics.
div.p: WE call a Medicine Sudorific when it procures Sweating, and Diaphoretic, when it works by inenible Tranpiration. They are both endu'd with a power to drive the Seroities outwards, by putting the Mas of Blood in Motion.

Guaiacum, Saraparilla, Butter-Burr, Carduus Benedictus, wild Marjoram, Penyroyal, Thyme, Sage, Sweet Marjoram, Bay-Berries, Corn Poppies, Treacle, and Brandy, are Sudorifics. The Doe of the Roots is from half an Ounce to an Ounce and a half to each Quart of the Decoction; and the Doe of the Leaves is a handful.

The Shavings of Harts-Horn, from one Dram to two, is both Sudorific and Cordial; as are alo thoe of Ivory, from a Dram to a Dram and a half. They mut be taken in two Ounces of Carduus and Baum-Water; and the Patient mut be kept very warm in Bed.

div.head: Of Sneezing Medicines and Errhina.
div.p: SNeezing being occaion'd by the Irritation communicated from the inferiour Membrane to the Dura Mater, by the mediation of the Olfactory Nerves, caues a Contraction by the reflux of the Spirit into the Carnous Fibres; o that the Motion of the Spirits being almot entirely topt for ome time after the Preure is over, they run mot impetuouly into the freet and openet Paages, which are thoe that are betow'd upon the Mucles of Repiration. And therefore when one neezes after the Contraction is over, he finds always ome difficulty in Breathing.

From hence it may be inferr'd, that uch Remedies as provoke Sneezing are very ueful in the Obtructions of the Subtance of the Brain, becaue the Dura Mater preing the Spirits, communicates to them a ufficient degree of Motion, to make way for themelves.

The mot common Sneezing Medicines are Betony, Tobacco, Pellitory of Spain, Sage, Sweet
Marjoram, Ginger, and all other Plants which abound with a harp Salt.
Thee Remedies mut be avoided in the Epilepie, Convulions, and in the Hyterical Paion, becaue they encreae thoe Ditempers which conit in a diorderly Motion of the Spirits.

Errhina are Medicines which bring forth mucous and impure Humours from the Noe without Sneezing. They may be made of the Juice or Decoctions of thoe Plants which I have already recommended for Sneezing.

div.head: Of Incraating or Thickening Medicines.
div.p: THey are uch as fix and put a top to the inordinate Motion in the Mas of the Blood, occaion'd by the eating of uch things as are full of harp and volatil Salts.
Decoctions made of the Roots of Succory, Sorrel, Marh-Mallows, Water-Lily, &c. are of this nature. The Doe of the Roots is an Ounce or an Ounce and a half to each Quart of the Decoction.
The Leaves of Purlain, Lettice, Sorrel, and of wild and Garden Succory, produce the ame effect, if a handful of all together be added to each Quart of the Ptian or Decoction.

The four greater Cold Seeds, viz. Cucumbers, Gourds, Citruls, and Melons, and the four leer Cold Seeds, viz. Lettice, Purlan, and both
orts of Endive, produce the ame effect. The Doe of all together may amount to half an Ounce in Emulions. They are ueful in heat of Urine.
The Juice of Limons, from half an Ounce to an Ounce, may alo be reckon'd an Incraating Remedy.

div.head: Of Narcotics, or Medicines that procure Sleep.
div.p: THey quiet the unuual and preternatural Motion of the Mucles, and the violent Convulions of the Nervous Parts, by Procuring a peaceable and quiet Sleep.

When they reach the Mas of the Blood, they unite themelves to the Spirits, and hinder both their Action and Separation; for thee Medicines are compos'd of Volatile Sulphurs mixt with Terretrial and Oily Particles. They are frequently given to thoe who are Delirious or Light-headed; as alo to uch as are troubl'd with violent and obtinate Evacuations.
The four Cold Seeds, either greater or leer, taken from a Dram to half an Ounce, in any convenient Liquor, may be ued for this purpoe.
The Roots of Henbane applied externally, by way of Cataplam, may alo erve to procure Sleep.
Opium may be alo taken, from half a Grain to two or three Grains.

div.head: Of Styptics or Atringents.
div.p: BInding or Atringent Medicines diipate the Serous Particles of the Blood, and render it les fluid. They mut not be us'd in the beginning of Evacuations that are et on foot by Nature, which mut not be topt for ome Days, according to the Age and Strength of the Patient.
Rhubarb may be profitably us'd in uch caes, from a Scruple to a Dram. Nor ought Claret to be omitted on uch occaions.

div.head: Of Carminative Medicines.
div.p: THey are uch as diipate and expel Wind. The mot Natural and mot Common Carminatives are Cloves, the Seeds of Anie, Fennel, and Coriander; and 'tis to be oberved, that they are more agreeable to the Stomach when they are confected and cruted over with Sugar, or mixt with Comfits.
If you are troubl'd with Wind in the lower part of your Belly, you mut prepare a Clyter of a Decoction of thoe Seeds, with an Ounce of the Oil of Walnuts.
Having given you a hort Account of Medicines in general, I hall proceed in the next place to mention ome Specific and particular Medicines, which in the Schools are call'd Topical Remedies.
'Tis to be oberv'd, that before the ue of thoe particular Medicines, you mut evacuate the groer Impurities by Clyters, and leen the exceive quantity of the Blood by Bleeding.

div.head: A Remedy for the Head-Ach.
div.p: WHEN the Head-Ach proceeds from Phlegm, or from a Cold Caue, which is known by a Drowines and Heavines of the Head, the Brain mut be purg'd thus:

Take the Leaves of Roemary, Thyme, Betony, and Sweet Marjoram, of each a handful; dry them in the Sun, or in an Oven, beat them to Powder, and ift 'em thro' a Searce. Take a convenient Doe of this Powder every Morning and Evening, about an Hour or two before you eat. It mitigates the Pain of the Head by purging the Brain.
But when the Ditemper proceeds from heated Choler, you mut provoke Sleep with ome of the Remedies mention'd in the Chapter that treats of Narcotics.

div.head: Againt the Apolexy.
div.p: YOU mut immediately open the Patient's Teeth with a Spoon, and put into his Mouth everal large Corns of Salt; then Bleed him in the Arm, and apply Cupping-Glaes with all convenient peed.

div.head: Againt the Palie.
div.p: TAke two Ounces of rectified Spirit of Wine, three Ounces of Oil of Bays; mix them with an Ounce of Balam of Peru, and having incorporated 'em together, make a Liniment, with which you mut anoint the Part affected, and wrap it up with a Linen-Cloth as hot as you can.

div.head: A Remedy for the Rheumatim, hard Swellings in the Joynts, for all Cold Swellings, and to trengthen the Nerves.
div.p: TAke four or five handfuls of Sage, beat it with a Pound of freh Butter; then boil all together for a Quarter of an Hour; after which train it through a coure Cloth, and rub the Parts affected with the Straining melting the Ointment every time you ue it.

div.head: To Purge Melancholy.
div.p: TAke Polypody of the Oak and Tops of Hops, of each half an Ounce, and boil 'em with two or three Rennet-Apples cut in Slices, in a ufficient quantity of Water. Then train the Decoction thro' a Linen-Cloth, and infue in it two or three Drams of Sena, with as much beaten Annieeds as you can take up between your Fingers and your Thumb.
Take this Medicine in the Morning, and about two Hours after drink ome Broath.

div.head: To Purge Choler.
div.p: MAke a Broath or Decoction of Lettice, Purlane, and Succory; infue in it according to the Seaon a handful of March Violets, Peach-Flowers, or Pale Roes, and take it in the Morning fating.
You may alo take half an Ounce of Conerve of Pale Roes fating, and a little after take a Broath made of cooling Herbs.

div.head: To Purge Phlegm.
div.p: BOil fifteen Grains of Aarabacca-Leaves in a-ufficient quantity of Wine, with a little Mint or Baum. Take three or four Spoonfuls of the train'd Liquor in the Morning fating, and an Hour or two after drink a little Broath.

div.head: For the Itching of the Eye-Lids.
div.p: TAke an Ounce of White-Wine, as much Roe-Water, a Dram of Hepatic or Liver-Aloes in Powder, mingle 'em together, and apply a piece of fine Linen dipt in this Liquor to the Eyes.

div.head: For an Inflammation in the Eyes.
For Deafnes.
div.p: TAke Juice of Onions, and Brandy, of each an Ounce and a half; mix them together, and put ome Drops of the Mixture lukewarm into the Ears, and afterwards top 'em with Cotton.

div.head: To top Bleeding at the Noe.
div.p: LAY a Key upon the Patient's Back, betwixt the Shirt and the Skin; or throw a Glas of cold Water in his Face.
A Stone of Cyprus-Vitriol put into the Notrils, tanches the Blood.
The ame Vitriol is alo good to cure Ulcers in the Mouth, by touching them two or or three times with it; but you mut not wallow your Spittle after it.

div.head: To Cure a Red Face, and take away the Pimples.
div.p: DIolve a ufficient quantity of Cyprus-Vitriol in Plantain-Water; and when you go to Bed, wah the Pimples with a little Cotton dipt in the Solution; and in the Morning wah your Face with River or Fountain-Water.

div.head: For Shortnes of Breath.
div.p: DRink a Glas of Mead in the Morning for Eight Days; and if that be not ufficient, put into it five or ix Drops of Spirit of Tobacco.

div.head: For Obtructions of the Lungs.
div.p: TAke Jujubes, Sebetens, dry'd Figs, Damask-Raiins, and ton'd Dates, of each half a Pound; Dogs-Gras, Liver-Wort, Hyop, the Leaves and Flowers of Colts-Foot and Scolopendria, of each a handful; the four Capillary Herbs, of each half a handful; Liquorice four Ounces; and three Pounds of Sugar. Make a Syrup of all; ue it often, and wallow it as lowly as you can.

div.head: For the Pleuriie.
div.p: TAke half an ordinary Glas-full of the Juice of Buglos or Borage, and an equal quantity of the Juice of Broom; Mix them together, and drink the Mixture warm before you go to Bed; lying upon that ide where you feel the Pain, or upon your Back.

div.head: For a Cold.
div.p: TAke a Spoonful of Oil of Sweet Almonds, two Spoonfuls of Syrup of Violets, and a Glas of Ptian; mix them together, and drink off the whole when you go to Bed.

div.head: To top Vomitting.
div.p: TAke a Spoonful of the Juice of Pomegranates or of Limons, and half a Dram of Salt of Wormwood; mix them for a Draught.

div.head: To Strengthen the Liver.
div.p: TAke a Pound of the Juice of Endive, and an Ounce of the Juice of Burnet; mix them well together, and take half a Glas every Morning for eight or fifteen Days.

div.head: For the Spleen.
div.p: TAke two handfuls of the Leaves of Harts-Tongue, chop them, and put them into a trong Bottle, with two Pints of White-Wine; cover the Bottle with a piece of thick Cap-Paper, making everal Holes with a Pin in it; then boil the Wine oftly till it ink a few Inches in the Bottle. Take half a Glas of this Liquor in the Morning fating, for eight Days.

div.head: For the Jaundice.
div.p: TAke the Dung of a young Gooe, Chicken, or Hen, dry it in the Sun, and beat it to Powder. Take from half a Dram to a Dram of this Powder every Morning in a Glas of White-Wine, with a little Sugar and Cinamon, for eight Days.

div.head: For the Dropie.
div.p: TAke half a Glas of Juice of Chervil, with an equal quantity of White-Wine, and about two Hours after drink a little Broath.

You mut continue the ue of this Medicine till the Swelling be abated; and in the mean time drink very moderately. Infue Burnet in Water, and mix it with an equal quantity of White-Wine for your ordinary Drink.

div.head: For the Nephritical Colic, or Stone in the Kidneys.
div.p: TAke two Ounces of Oil of Sweet Almonds drawn without Fire, with a like quantity of Juice of Limons, or Citrons; or, if you pleae, you may take the Oil in two Ounces of White-Wine.

div.head: For the Bilious Colic.
div.p: TAke Roe-Water, and Oil of Sweet Almonds, drawn without Fire, of each two Ounces; mix them for a Draught.

div.head: For the Wind Colic.
div.p: TAke a greaie Dihclout, and apply it pretty hot to the Belly, or where you feel the Pain. Renew it often.

div.head: Another.
div.p: DRY a handful of common Salt, put it in a Linen Cloth, and apply it pretty warm to the place affected.

div.head: For all orts of Colics.
div.p: TAke a Dram of Walnut-Flowers in Powder, in a Glas of White-Wine.

div.head: For a Looenes.
div.p: TAke every three Hours a Pint of Cow's-Milk boil'd with the Yolk of an Egg, about half an Ounce of Sugar, and as much White-Bread as you think fit: You mut neither eat nor drink any thing ele; and beides you mut keep your elf in Bed, or at leat in a dry and warm place.

div.head: For a Dyentery.
div.p: TAke two Ounces of Oil of Sweet Almonds drawn without Fire; or, if that cannot be had, take the like quantity of Sweet Oil-Olive, two Ounces of Roe-Water, and one Spoonful of Sugar. Mix them all together for a Draught to be taken in the Morning fating.
The Signs of a Dyentery are a Looenes accompany'd with a griping Pain, and the voiding of Blood, or Excrements mixt with Blood.
About two Hours after the taking of the above-mention'd Medicine, you may drink ome Broath, and eat a new-laid Egg.
You may make your Broath with a Leg of Mutton, or a Cock.

So long as the Ditemper lats, you mut take a Clyter every Day made only of the Decoction of Barley and Bran; and when you are jut ready to take it, add the Yolks
of two raw Eggs, with a little Sugar, and beat them well together.
You mut be let Blood once or twice in the Arm, and mut drink nothing but a Ptian made of the Decoction of Barley and Liquorice.
You mut not take a purging Medicine till eight or ten Days after the Cure.
Then you may take half an Ounce of Catholicum diolv'd in about four Ounces of Roe-Water.

div.head: For the Worms.
div.p: TAke two Spoonfuls of the Juice of Limons or Citrons, with the like quantity of Sweet Oil, or of White-Wine, and mix them for a Draught to be taken in the Morning fating.

div.head: For the Worms in little Children.
div.p: CHafe the Belly about the Navel with Oil of Bitter Almonds, and lay a Plaiter of Aloes over it.

div.head: For the Piles either Internal or External, whether they void Blood or not.
div.p: TAke mall Male Sengreen, or Prick-Madam, and freh Butter a ufficient quantity, beat 'em together in a Mortar, and apply it to the Part, renewing it three or four times a Day.

div.head: For the Pain of the Kidneys.
div.p: DIP a Linen Cloth in Oxycrate, and apply it to the Part affected.
Oxycrate is a Mixture of ix parts of Water, and one of Vinegar.

div.head: For the Stoppage or Suppreion of the rine.
div.p: INfue an Ounce of Lineed in a Pound of River or Fountain-Water, for twenty four Hours. If it be in the Summer, you mut infue it in a cool place; and if in the Winter, in warm Ahes. Afterwards train it off, and put it into a Glas Bottle. Drink a Glas of it every Morning, Noon, and Night.

div.head: To bring down the Coures.
div.p: BEAT two or three Heads of Garlick, and make a Plaiter of them, which mut be apply'd to the lower par • of the Back, on the Right-Side.

div.head: To top the immoderate Flux of Blood which happens to Women in Labour, or after they are brought to Bed.
div.p: INject two or three Clyters of Oxycrate every Day.

div.head: For the Suffocation of the Womb.
div.p: Take an Ounce of Cinamon cut into mall Pieces, three Ounces of fine Sugar in Powder; mix them, and add four Ounces of Roe-Water, and ix Ounces of trong Brandy; let them tand twelve Hours in Infuion, train it two or three times thro' a Woollen Cloth, and keep the Liquor in a Glas-Vial.
The Patient may take two or three Spoonfuls of this Liquor, to prevent the Return of a Paroxym; and even during the Fit, that he may be the ooner delivered from it.

div.head: For Fits of the Mother.
div.p: TAke a handful of the Herb call'd Avens, beat it, and infue it for the pace of an Hour or two in a Pint of White-Wine, and let the Patient drink a little of it when h • is thirty.

div.head: For a Woman in Labour, to haten her Delivery.
div.p:
TAke the Liver and Gall of the fattet Eel you can procure, dry 'em in an Oven after the Bread is drawn out, and beat 'em to Powder. The Doe is one
Dram in three or four Spoonfuls of the bet Wine.

div.head: To expel a dead Child.
div.p: GIve the Sick Woman an Ounce of the Juice of Hyop, in half a Glas of warm Water, with a Spoonful of Brandy.

div.head: For the Colic, or griping Pain of the Belly, which frequently aaults Women that are newly deliver'd.
div.p: TAke Orange-Flower-Water, and Syrup of Maidenhair, of each two Ounces; mix and <> a Draught.

div.head: To bring Milk into the Breats of Women that are newly deliver'd.
div.p: GIve the Woman a Dram of the Powder of Fennel-eed in Cabbage-Broath, or in a Glas of White-Wine.

div.head: For thoe who have too much Milk.
div.p:
TAke Roe-Water and Verjuice, of each two Ounces; mix them together with five or ix Grains of Salt; heat the Mixture upon a Chafing-Dih; then dip a Linen Cloth four or five times doubl'd, in the Liquor, and apply it warm to the Breat, laying over it two pieces of Linen well
heated. You mut renew the Application twice a Day; and if the Ditemper continue, you mut apply it alo the Day following.

div.head: To dry up the Milk in thoe who are not willing to uckle their Children.
div.p: TAke a Bitter Orange, pierce it in everal places with the Point of a Knife, or with a Bodkin, queeze out the Juice, and put the Orange into a little Earthen-Pot, which you mut fill with Oil-Olive; boil away two thirds of the Oil, and then rub the Breats with it very oftly, and as warm as it can be endured.

div.head: For the Inflammation of the Breats.
div.p: TAke the Crum of a White-Loaf, boil it in a ufficient quantity of Milk; add an Ounce of Oil of Lilies, and make a Pultis, which mut be apply'd to the Breat.

div.head: For the Fits of a Tertian-Ague.
div.p: IN the beginning of the third and fourth Fit, take half a Glas of the Juice of Borage, mixt with the like quantity of White-Wine; but you mut take a Clyter, and be let Blood the Night before.

div.head: For an Intermitting Fever.
div.p: TAke a handful of the Leaves of Burnet, Infue them twelve Hours in a Pint of White-Wine; then train out the Wine thro' a Linen Cloth, and give the Patient half a Glas of it at the beginning of the cold Fit, continuing after the ame in the three or four ucceeding Fits.

div.head: For a Quartan Ague.
div.p: DIolve the Yolk of a new-laid Egg in a Glas of Wine, and drink it at the beginning of the cold Fit.

div.head: For a Purple Fever.
div.p: TAke the Leaves of Wood-Sorrel, Scabious, Carduus Benedictus, and Queen of the Meadows, of each one handful; boil them in a ufficient quantity of River or Fountain-Water. To the train'd Liquor add four Drops of the Spirit of Vitriol, and half an Ounce of ine Sugar.
Let the Patient take half a Glas of this Liquor before or during the Fit, continuing after the ame manner five or ix Days.
Let him drink a Ptian made with Barberries and Scorzonera-Roots.
Let him not take a purging Medicine till the Fever diappear.

div.head: For the Plague.
div.p: MElt an Ounce of old Hogs-Greae, with a like quantity of Honey; then remove the Veel from the Fire, and add an Ounce of Rie-Meal, and two Yolks of Eggs, tirring them all the while. Spread this Ointment upon Leather, and apply it to the Bubo's, changing it twice a Day.
When a Carbuncle or Bubo is uppurated, and breaks, put into it a Tent dipt in the ame Ointment, and lay a Pultis over it.

div.head: For Carbuncles or Plague-Sores.
div.p: TAke the Ointments Populeon and Bailicon, of each one Ounce; mix them, and preading a ufficient quantity upon a piece of Leather, apply it to the Sore till the Scab or Echar fall off.

div.head: A Remedy for Corns.
div.p: BOil a ufficient quantity of the Crum of Brown-Bread in Milk, to the thicknes of Broath; and after you take it off from the Fire, add to it a proportionable quantity of nguentum Roatum, pread it upon Linen, and apply it to the Corn.

div.head: To preerve the Face from being mark'd by the Small-Pox.
div.p: DIP a Feather in Oil of Sweet Almonds, drawn without Fire, and anoint the Pocks as they come out for the pace of Nine or Ten Days.

div.head: To preerve the Sight in the Small-Pox.
Another.
div.p:
TAke a piece of Gold, heat it red-hot in the Fire, quench it everal times in Plantain-Water, and pour ome Drops of the Water into the Eyes of the Patient. You mut continue in the ue of this Remedy from the firt appearance of the Small-Pox,
• or the pace of three Weeks or a Month.

div.head: For the Sciatica.
div.p:
TAke Mutard-eed and Figs, of each two Ounces; beat 'em to a Mah, which mut be apply'd like a Plaiter to the Part
• ffected, and often renew'd.

div.head: For the Itch.
div.p: AFter you have been let Blood in the Arm, and purg'd, according to your Strength and Contitution, rub the Palms of your Hands, your Writs, the Soles of your Feet, and even your whole Body, with an Ointment made of two Ounces of freh Butter, and half an Ounce of the Flower of Brimtone, well mixt together: warm it every time you ue it: And that it may work more effectually, you may anoint your elf near the Fire.

div.head: For a Tetter or Ring-Worm.
div.p: TAke three Drams of new Wax, melt it with four Ounces of Oil of Roes, and two Ounces of Honey of Roes. When 'tis all melted, take it off the Fire, and put to it an Ounce of Soot, and half an Ounce of Cerus in Powder; tirring it till it be cold. When you have occaion to ue it, pread it upon a Linen Cloth, and apply it to the Part affected.

div.head: For a Cut or Wound.
div.p: TAke a red-hot Coal out of the Fire, beat it to Powder, and put ome of it into the Wound. It will immediately tanch the Blood.

div.head: For Burning.
div.p: TAke four Spoonfuls of Water, in which unlack'd Lime has been quench'd, the like quantity of Oil of Nuts, and beat them up to the thicknes of a Liniment; then anoint the burnt Part with a Feather, and cover it with brown Paper.

div.head: To open all orts of Tumours without a Lance.
div.p: TAke freh Butter and Verjuice, of each two Ounces, mix and boil them together: Dip a fine Linen Rag, or piece of brown iue-Paper into the Liquor, and apply it pretty hot to the Place affected.

div.head: For all orts of Inflammations that happen either before or after the Breaking of a Tumour.
div.p: TAke a fine Linen Rag, dip it in Oxycrate or Water; then pread a little of Galen's Ceratum upon it, (which may be found at any Apothecary's Shop) and apply it to the inflamed Part.

div.head: For Bruies.
div.p: TAke a quarter of a Pint of thick Red-Wine, two Ounces of freh Butter, two Pugils of Provence Roes, and one Pugil of Wheat-Bran; boil all together to the thicknes of Broath, pread it upon a Linen Cloath, and apply it to the Part affected.

div.head: For all orts of Wounds.
div.p: TAke a Pound of freh Butter, a quarter of a Pint of the Juice of Sage, the like quantity of the Juice of Wall-Wort, an Ounce of Bay-Berries in Powder, with a quarter of a Pint of good Wine.
Boil all together in a Veel upon the Fire, to the thicknes of an Ointment, or till the Moiture be conum'd, and reerve it for ue.

div.head: For all Gun-hot Wounds.
div.p: TAke two Ounces of Birth-Wort, either long or round, put it into an Earthen Pipkin with three quarters of a Pint of Wine, and boil away one half; then take the Pot from the Fire, and put in two Ounces of Sugar. Keep this Liquor for ue in a Glas-Bottle.

When the Wound is large, lay on the firt Dreing with the Whites of two Eggs beat up to a Froth, to which add a Dram or two of Bol • -Armenic in Powder; then pread the whole upon the Tow of fine Hemp, and leave it upon the Wound till the ame Hour next Day. After twenty four Hours you mut take away the firt Dreing, put ome of this Water into a Spoon, heat it lukewarm, dip a Linen Rag in it, and wah the Wound; and lay upon it another piece of Linen dipt in the ame Water: taking care to keep the Wound always Moit.

div.head: For all orts of lcers.
div.p:
TAke Burgundy-Pitch, Roin, and new Wax, of each two Ounces; put them all into an Earthen-Pipkin, and melt them on the Fire; then add ix Ounces of freh Butter, with a Dram of Vardigr • ae in Powder,
tirring 'em all the while. Put this Balam into an Earthen Pot, and keep it for ue.

div.head: For a Gangrene.
div.p: INfue half a Pound of nlak'd Lime for the pace of ix Hours, in a Pint of Smith's-Water; then pour it off oftly, without removing the Veel. In this Water infue a Dram of Sublimate for the pace of a Night. Then add a ixth part of rectified Spirit of Wine, and pour it all off without tirring the Sediments. Wah the gangren'd parts every Morning, Noon, and Night, with this Water a little heated.

div.head: OF Ptians or Decoctions.
div.p:
THEY may be prepar'd everal ways, according to the various Ues they are made for. The mot common are Purgative, Laxative, Cooling, and Pectoral; tho' many other orts may be made, according to the different Ditempers that attack Human Bodies. But I hall only mention
thoe that are mot frequently us'd, and mot eaily prepar'd.

div.head: A Cooling, Opening, and Pectoral Ptian.
div.p: TAke half a Peck of good Oats well cleans'd, wild Succory and Burnet, of each one handful; boil them oftly in a Gallon of River-Water, for a large half Hour, or three quarters of an Hour; after which add half an Ounce of Sal Prunellae, with a quarter of a Pound of the bet Honey you can procure; and boil it again oftly for half an Hour: Then take it off the Fire, train it thro' a Linen Cloth, and pour the Liquor into an Earthen Pot. Take a Draught of it two Hours before, and two Hours after Meals.

div.head: A Purgative and Laxative Ptian.
div.p:
POur two Quarts of River or Fountain-Water, into a cloe Pot, and et it near the Fire; put into it half an Ounce of Sena, four or five Roots of Wild Succory, two little Sticks of Liquorice, more or les, according to the Palate of the Patient; and a Dram of Green Fennel-eed; then tye a Dram of the rapings of Ivory, and the like quantity of Harts-Horn in a Linen Rag; boil 'em a little longer with the ret of the Ingredients in the Pot, and afterwards train out the Liquor. Drink a Glas of it every
Morning fating for Eight or Ten Days.

div.head: A Pectoral Ptian.
div.p: TAke Jujubes, Sebeten, and Damask Raiins, of each one Ounce; a Stick of Liquorice beaten, and a quarter of a Pound of Honey; Boil them oftly in two Quarts of River-Water, for a quarter of an Hour; and afterwards train out the Liquor thro' a Linen Cloth. You may drink a Glas of it every Morning, and another at Night when you go to Bed; It mut neither be too hot nor too cold when you drink it.

div.head: OF SYRUPS, And their Vertues.
div.p: THE Syrups that are mot frequently us'd, are the Syrup of Pale Roes, the Syrup of Peach-Flowers, compound Syrup of Apples, compound Syrup of Succory. Syrup of Violets, Syrup of Maiden-hair, and the Syrup of Corn-Poppies.

The Syrup of Pale Roes erves to evacuate all orts of Seroities, either Phlegmatic, Bilious, or Melancholic; it trengthens the Stomach, and opens Obtructions in the Capillary Veels of the Liver, and of the ret of the Entrals.
The Syrup of Peach-Flowers is good for thoe who are Hydropical, and is particularly adapted for expelling Serous Humours.
Compound Syrup of Apples evacuates the Melancholic Humour which infects the Mas of the Blood. It is alo very good to purge the Spleen.
Compound Syrup of Succory, prepra'd with Rhubarb, purges the redundant Bile, trengthens the Liver and Stomach, and opens Obtructions in other Parts of the Body.

Syrup of Violets purges Choler, cools, and promotes Expectoration: You may take an Ounce or a Spoonful of it in a Glas of Water; but you mut have two Glaes, and pour it out of one into the other everal times, to dilute the Syrup.
Syrup of Maiden-Hair is of excellent ue in Dieaes of the Breat; it frees it from the corrupt Humours that are log'd in it, and helps the ick Peron to pit.
Syrup of Corn-Poppies procures Sleep: The Doe is from an Ounce to two Ounces at Night.

div.head: FOR THE TOOTH-ACH.
div.p: AFTER Eating, you mut gargarize your Mouth, and wah your Gums with Wine and Water; then take the Ahes of the econd Bark of the Ah-Tree; mix 'em with a Spoonful of Brandy, and make a Plaiter, which mut be apply'd to the Temples on that ide where you feel the Pain.

div.head: Another.
div.p: PUT a Clove or two upon the aking Tooth, then hut your Teeth, and hang your Head on that ide where the Pain lies; this will draw out abundance of Water, and by that means give you eae.
If the Tooth be rotten or carious, you mut pull it out, or ele put a Drop of Aqua-Fortis into it.

div.head: A Cooling Clyter.
div.p: MAKE a Clyter of Oxycrate, that is, mix a Pint of lukewarm Water with ix Spoonfuls of Vinegar.

div.head: A Clyter for one who is Cotive.
div.p: TAke a quarter of a Pound of Oil of Nuts, and the like quantity of common Honey, put them into a Pint of Water, and if you are troubl'd with Gripes, add as much Powder of Anie or Fennel-eed as you can take up between your Fingers and Thumb: If not, add half a quarter of a Pint of Vinegar, and boil it as uually.

div.head: A Clyter to top a Looenes.
div.p:
MAke a Decoction with White Mullein, Provence Roes, and Plantain, of each one handful; Lin-eed and Quince-eed, of each a Dram; half an Ounce of Starch, and
the Yolk of an Egg. In the beginning of a Looenes you ought not to make ue of Atringent Medicines, but mut let Nature act without diturbance for ome Days, according to the Age and Strength of the Patient.
